reviewText:
Call Of Juarez Gunslinger is an action packed first person shooter, set in the Wild West. It has big shootouts, duels, famous outlaws, you name it. Everything you would want from a game with a theme like this.

The story is told as a tale, so occasionally the story will rewind or change on the fly in order to adjust bits of the story. It's well integrated and it's a fun way to keep the story fresh. Now, this game is all about shooting so it's important that this part works well. Thankfully, it does.

The shooting aspect is tight and the reward system behind it is solid as well. Killing enemies will reward you with XP and if you kill enemies fast enough you'll build up a combo meter that will reward you with even more experience. There's also a focus key that will slow the game down so you can kill enemies more easily.

The skill trees are diverse (for a shooter, so don't expect any skills that don't belong here) and allow you to mix things up fairly well.

Graphically the game looks awesome. It has a realistic look with what looks like a little bit of cel shading in it.

For a downloadable game Gunslinger is pretty long. It took me roughly 8 hours to complete the story. After that, you can start a new game with New Game Plus.
If you have no interest in starting over again, there's always the Duel and Arcade modes.
Duel will have you duel (duh) against all of the enemy bosses from the story, with only 5 lives, and Arcade will put in your several levels of the game with cleverly placed enemies. The goal there is to kill enemies as fast as you can while building up your combo meter. A fun, very fun, challenge. In fact, I think I had more fun with the Arcade mode than the Story mode but that's because the Arcade mode is fast paced and allows for replayabilty, even if a level is only a few minutes long. Collecting 3 stars on all levels should take you a long time.

Gunslinger managed to truly impress me. But then again, I was already looking forward to playing this as there really aren't enough games around like this (I count The Club as one of them, more or less). It's now one of my favorite games of this year. I hope it does well enough to give us a possible sequel... downloadable or retail.

[Rating: 93/100]

reviewText:
Silas Greaves is probably full of ♥♥♥♥, but that’s OK. He’s a bounty hunter with a million stories to tell, and happy to share them for a whisky or five. Like the times he rode with Billy the Kid, or when he won the praise of Injun magic men, or that shootout he had with Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (simultaneously). In short, tales of hanging out with just about every celebrity in the Wild West... and convenient excuses for why nobody can quite remember seeing him there.

This isn’t just a framing device for Gunslinger’s nine missions, but a big part of what helps this downloadable budget title wash away the foul taste of Call of Juarez: The Cartel. As expected, it’s a linear shooter set in a romanticised version of the Wild West (which the game itself at one point admits is complete balls). It’s also a shooter Greaves and his audience comment on throughout, the narration routinely changing the world to fit the story on the fly. At one point, for instance, you fight through a mine full of dynamite that only an idiot would go into with guns blazing. “That’s why I didn’t,” rasps Greaves, rewinding the story to tell it ‘properly’.

This doesn’t disguise the linearity, but it does make the straight path much more interesting. My only big complaint about the execution – aside from the fact that the dialogue was recorded as individual lines, and so usually fails to mesh into a smooth narrative – is that Techland didn’t use this gimmick on a full-budget game with scope for even bigger, more varied setpieces.

Restricting Juarez to raw gunplay certainly doesn’t hurt it, because the shooting is excellent. While not rewriting the rules of FPS, there’s a real weight to the weapons, while the action is a mix of regular shootouts and switching to a special slow-mo Concentration mode to take out whole groups in the blink of an eye. This ability regenerates quickly, providing an interesting power balance where you can’t take much damage, but regularly get to go full ‘Angel of Death’ on whole crowds. There’s also a very clever system where, with enough charge, you get a 50/50 chance of dodging a slowed-down incoming bullet that would normally be lethal. Get it right and you stay in the fight.

Combined, the two parts work beautifully. The story keeps things slightly off-balance and constantly throws up interesting moments, while the minute-by-minute gunplay makes murdering your way through that story intensely satisfying.

Yes, the graphics – and the cutscenes illustrated with static, hand-drawn images – are constant reminders that this is a budget game. Far from being diminished by that, however, Gunslinger impresses with just how well it spent its pennies. And, more impressively still, it makes the idea of another Call of Juarez game at some time in the future surprisingly appealing.

reviewText:
Presentation
There are certain parts of history that seem like an endless supply of ideas for new stories and settings, and the Wild West is one of the greatest examples to prove that point. Call of Juarez Gunslinger uses that exact period in time to tell a great, believable and unexpected story using a combination of fictional stories and characters with actual events and legends from the American West. You play as Silas Greaves, one of the few fictional characters created to fill the bucket of an already enormous cast of Wild West legends, such as Billy the Kid, Jesse James or the Sundance Kid. The story unfolds as Silas Greaves tells more about his adventures to the young and old adventurers alike, listening to his stories at The Bull's Head Saloon. His narration is part of what makes this story so unique, as things will happen and events will chance according to the story he tells you and the interaction he has with the other characters taking part in the conversation at the saloon, adding things according to how they recall it happened or approving of things that Silas says, adding more context to the story. While the story is relatively small, taking around six hours to complete, the places you visit and enemies you will fight will make each moment of it feel memorable and unique, as you will one moment go head to head against one of the Dalton brothers, only to face Jesse James himself shooting a gatling gun your way the next one. In the same manner the locations will differ, offering a new and refreshing experience with each chapter, taking you from a vast canyon to a cave, only to then end up on a moving train, being a part of one of the biggest events in the American West history.
Rating: 9.5

Gameplay
In a crowd of modern military first person shooters, Gunslinger manages to stand out by using intuitive and easy to use mechanics that reward you based on how you play and give you the option to choose in which direction you want to go forward. This feature comes as a result of the skill tree, that allows you to unlock a new skill each time you level up, which can be done by collecting enough experience of course. Depending on how you play and manage your abilities you might earn you more or less experience, but the game never stops you from earning more, even after you get to the end of the game, as the New Game Plus mode will allow you to start a new game with a different difficulty level while carrying over all your unlocked skills and remaining experience points. There are two main abilities that will be unlocked from the start, with the option to improve or modify how those work and how long it takes for them to charge, and using them in an efficient way will prove to be the key later the game or in arcade mode if you're going for the highest score. Bullet time will slow down time, highlighting the enemies ahead of you and giving you a better chance at scoring headshots and combos, while bullet dodge will automatically activate when you are low on health and about to get hit by a fatal bullet, allowing you to move left or right in order to avoid it. Aside from the campaign, the arcade mode works in a similar way, allowing you to choose at the beginning of each level a specific loadout and unlock more skills to use with that loadout and improve the possible outcome as you play more and earn more experience.
Rating: 9

Graphics
Call of Juarez Gunslinger might not be the best looking game out there, but its unique art style does a great job hiding that, as the game's art style comes pretty close to what you would see on the cover of a dime novel, and with Silas' constant narration of the story, the entire game feels like you were actually experiencing the wild stories of the west seen through the eyes of Silas Greaves. The visual effects, while not stunning, manage to mix in with the scenery in a way that makes them feel natural and a part of the environment, even if some times they are out of place. The highest detail was of course put into the wild west legends themselves, making characters such as Jesse James look stunning and closely to what you would imagine him to look like if you were to stand right next to him.
Rating: 7.5

Audio
While it might not be as memorable and big as the soundtrack of other western themed games such as Red Dead Redemption, the tracks that are here manage to always stay in the mood with the action and when one of those rare moments of less shooting and more beauty comes along, there is always a good tune to add to the view. The voice acting is excellent and while some of the characters which are only part of Silas' story and do not actually stand with him in the saloon rarely speak, the ones that do take part in the dispute happening at the saloon over facts and how things went down are treated with a high quality voice that makes them come to life, with the honorable mention of Silas Greaves himself which is the narrator for most of the stories.
Rating: 8

Extras
The campaign can be completed within six hours, but the fact that the story has two possible outcomes and that the New Game Plus mode which will unlock once you have completed the game for the first time allows you to start a new campaign and keep all your progress at the same time makes this experience be worth at least another replay. Aside from that you have the Duel Mode which is a recollection of all the duels throughout the story where you can improve your reaction time and compete for the highest scores, and Arcade Mode which is all about the leaderboards and the stars you can earn. There is no multiplayer mode, but with all there is to do as it is, you can easily spend around 15 hours in the game without even realizing it.
Rating: 9

Verdict
Call of Juarez Gunslinger is one of the best western experiences to date, and while it not might be as full of content as other titles on the market, it manages to tell an interesting story by using actual Wild West legends in combination with some newly created characters that have their unique personalities and role into the story. Aside from that, for the 15 bucks you pay for the game at full price, you get at least 15 hours of pure entertainment and maybe even more if you're digging the arcade mode and aim for a top position on the leaderboards.
Rating Overall: 8.6

Check out the full review and a lot more about Call of Juarez: Gunslinger at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=292[/h1]

reviewText:
Abridged summary can be read at the very end of this review.
What starts off as an entertaining little arcade shooter ends up filling a void I never realized was missing. As someone who doesn't often touch a modern FPS game, I may not have a whole lot of experience to describe why I think this game is worth so much more in $15 than most games earn for the $60 they demand, but I can at least describe why I love this game immensely.

To start, it's a fairly linear narrative-driven shooter, and that alone would have put me off in the light of Medal of Battle: Dutyfield games that have defined the genre in the past couple generations. But this game manages to stand between the modern conventions of shooters and the classic mechanics I remember from sneaking onto our old Compaq PC to play Doom or Duke Nukem when I was supposed to be in bed.

Games these days can't get away with some kind of RPG progression system, but Gunslinger does away with the tedium of it by offering little perks that don't define how you play the game but just enhance it in non-essential ways. The exception would be the titual Gunslinger perk that allows you to dual-wield revolvers, with that being the only gain that offers a genuine mechanical difference. Otherwise, leveling up gives you slight advantages that make the game feel a bit more action-heavy and faster paced.

The levels in the game are surprisingly massive, which actually comes as a drawback to the experience, as in many cases I found myself lost until I hit a point where I was told I was leaving the story zone and had to turn around. Why these levels allow you to reach places so far from the objective is beyond me, as there is rarely anything to find outside of the scripted mission path. There are a load of secrets to find in each level, but they are placed in little nooks and crannies amidst the mission zone that it makes no sense to let you wander so far away.

The showdown mode, which stands in place of a boss fight in several levels, is what it is. You stand there, waiting and observing your enemy, baiting them to draw first yet finish last. It requires you to focus as much on your character as on your enemy, so there is a good bit of skill involved, but there is an artificial difficulty added by the immense sway of your crosshairs that is incredibly difficult to predict or compensate for. This system could use a lot of work, mechanically, but it's hard to fault them when I haven't quite seen anything like it since the original Red Dead Revolver, at the very least.

The gunplay is a load of fun. It's a fast-paced shooter where the simple objective is to out-bullet your enemies. Stealth is usually only a mechanic at the very beginning of a level - once you fire a shot, it's all out chaos. This is mitigated by a bullet-time mode that, with perks, can allow you to dodge bullets, line up headshots, and reload or swap weapons in a blink. Apart from that, the game occasionally sucks you into a QTE-mode to dodge bullets in a life-or-death scenario, or in scripted events that depend on precise reaction to button prompts to take out enemies quickly. I hate QTE's with a firm passion, but at least this game almost never relies on instant-death ones, instead requiring you to take them down the old fashioned way.

Being such an action-focused game, it's hard to believe that it has a surprisingly deep story. At first, the depth presents itself in its history-rich narrative, involving characters from classic American Western folklore, played up in a balance between recorded history and the first-hand account of an unreliable narrator. It's incredibly entertaining to watch how everything from the narrative to the enemies to the landscape itself gets reimagined as the player character recounts his tale to his imaginative audience. Your protagonist, Silas Greaves, presents his account of the downfall of just about every famous Western outlaw or folk hero as he regales his tale of revenge. How much truth you choose to derive from his boasted tale is up to you, but it all culminates in a unique opportunity to define how it all ends.

TLDR version: Gunslinger is a fast-paced, action-packed shooter with a simple narrative that nevertheless drew me in deep and left me with a burning desire for more games of its caliber. I dearly hope that this franchise (which I will admit I've never played before this game) continues in such a direction, as I have not played such a compelling and satisfying single-player shooter in a very, very long time.

reviewText:
I remember all my friends buying Call of Juarez The Cartel when it first came out and constently bashing it, saying how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ it was, about how it's the worst game ever and ♥♥♥♥, the game all in all, was a critical failure, and everyone knew it, which is why when I first heard about CoJ Gunslinger, I was extremely sceptic, expected something horrible, had absolutely no faith in it, and then I downloaded the demo on my Xbox 360.

I was floored.

The gameplay was tense and intense yet fluid and fun, the story interest, the naration intertaining and visually stunning, not to mention the msic, which is always on point, so I ended up buying it on my pc.

Honestly all I can say is that this is one of, if not THE best shooting game I have ever played, worth every penny.

The duels are crazy, always different, most duels have some twists to them.

The gunfights are always tense and crazy, the bullet time incridibly satisfying as you see bullets go past your head and blood splatter everywhere and the music extremely fitting to most situations.

The story is interesting and a real homage to all the Spaguetti Western and is very satisfying and told in an very intertaining because since Silas Greaves (the protagonist) is telling his stories, and the gameplay and level changes as he tells them.

All in all this game is incredible, well worth the price.

reviewText:
Few things catch our attention like a deep voiced grown man who tells the story of his own life. And better yet, a life full of adventure and danger... And even better if those stories are placed in the Wild West, where a man only had his courage, his guns and a few bullets to become a legend.

Such is the story of Silas Greaves, a stubborn man who will stop at nothing or no one in his jurney for justice and revenge.

If you care for a good Western, this game has it all:
Fast paced, action packed shoot-outs
Beautiful scenery, complimented with awesome cartoonish graphics
Incredible story (littleraly), including mexican toe-to-toe standoffs with some of the most infamous outlaws of the wild west (such as Billy the Kid, Jesse James and many others)
And finally but not least, an amazing soundtrack
To me, this is a strong 9/10, a must play FPS.

reviewText:
Excellent short arcade FPS western. Great voice acting and characters to love. They bring in many true cowboys from history and weave them into a fun and action packed fictional story. The game can be beaten in around 7 hours but the whole time it's fun.

The story is told while you play as Silas Greaves, the main character, narrates his run ins with the various cowboys looking for the men who murdered his brothers. He tells the stories to a group of patrons in a bar who doubt his accuracy of his story telling on occasion. There are laughs to be had a twist to be discovered.

There are collectibles that are cards telling you real history of the wild west. Great things to find and read if you love the wild west. You will also earn xp in the game to level up Silas to make you and even better gunfighter. After beating the game it unlocks a new game + and true west modes. This adds some good replayability to the game if you are one who likes to try and achieve the highest score you can for each level.

Also when you find one of the main cowboys you can be thrown into a duel. You control your hand over your gun to try and build speed up for a quicker draw and also a reticle over the enemy to build your focus for better accuracy. The goal is to draw faster than them and win the duel. Once you hit about 75% accuracy though you can draw first and shoot them but you could get a dishonarble kill which doesn't get you bonus xp.

It's a great game to play and not be passed up. I definitely recommend this awesome game.

reviewText:
I remember playing the original Call of Juarez ages ago and thinking that it was a fun, if frivalous, affair. Not much has changed with the series in close to a decade.

This installment is still fun and full of the usual first person shooter mechanics, plus a couple special abilities for things like slow motion and highlighting enemies. Duels also make an expected return, and they're a nice change of pace from the franticness of most levels. It's generally snappy and well-executed, but there is a terrible lack of variety in both the weapons and enemies, which only have 3 and 4 unique types, respectively. So despite an ok length the gameplay feels small and repetitive. And this time around they introduced an RPG-like skill tree (a must for any FPS these days), but it doesn't really change anything so you're going to be using the same techniques - iron sights, fire, cover, reload - to dispatch the same enemies over and over again.

The production value is quite high though. The graphics look mostly great at 1440, though a few sprites (particularly the playing cards) are pixelated. The environments seem like they'd be really fun to explore, and I tried, but was constantly being pushed back by an invasive invisible wall with a warning that I was straying from the story." Yeah I was
date: that's exactly the point.\n\nThe voice acting is absolutely top notch. The accents and emotions are always appropriate and come through really nicely. A tip of my hat to whoever was behind the dialogue and the voice acting
recommended: because both deserve a lot of praise
hoursPlayed:
and the effort that was put into them is readily apparent.

If only that same time and effort had been put into the actual plot and story. It's essentially just a whirlwind meet and greet of every celebrity from the Wild West. There's no depth despite attempts at it in the eleventh hour. Far too little too late.

Really this game is the opposite of most: it's a fundamentally bad idea executed well. If there were a wider variety of enemies and guns
voteText: if you could explore more and it felt like a open world - even within the constraints of a linear
helpfulPercent: level-based progression - if the story actually drew you in and made you care about what happened
votesHelpful: then this game could have been amazing. But its core design just wasn't strong enough to make it more than average.\n\nSo if you want a solid Western FPS that's going to divert you for a bit
votesTotal: but be utterly forgettable when it's over
votesFunny: then this is the game for you. Plus for value the extras are really nice add-ons: both the arcade and duel modes were a fun way of getting more out of the game assets. But if you want something with a story or depth or originality you'd best look elsewhere. Pardner."

reviewText:
I recommend this game as the perfect 5 dollar game.  It's fun.  It has really fun gun play.  It's a linear shooter.  You are literally playing a FPS while someone is telling you a story based on actual historic events and people.  It does have a lot of cut scenes because of that.  I wasn't expecting that, so at first I was a little put off.  Now that I used to it, it's more tolerable.  It's the type of game you can jump into and play a few chapters, when you are bored with what you are currently playing, then take a break and get back to it whenever you want.  I don't think it'll suck you in where you'll get totally addicted.

It has a bunch of different modes to try out.  It has a lot of options in the game play.  It's graphically impressive.

What else can I say, it's fun.  That's the best way to describe it.  It's not groundbreaking, it won't change you life, it won't make you want to have it's babies, but it's just good old fashion, solid fun.

reviewText:
So partner are you feeling lucky? I sure was feeling lucky as I got Call of Juarez Gunslinger during the holiday sale for a really low price; and it was well worth the price.  If you’re a fan of westerns and you enjoy killing lots and lots of people then this game is entirely for you.

The story was interesting at times and overall was enjoyable, but there were parts where things just seemed dull and to obvious. The character acting was done well and gave a sense of individualism to each character. The game itself progresses decently but then at times takes a Borderlands-esk turn and quickly changes into some craziness. The basic direction behind each part of the story was kill a bunch of bad guys in some heroic way and then finish off some ringleader of each gang; like I said parts can be dull. The ending itself was decent and did leave me with closure.

Overall the sound and music were good but not great as some vocals from NPCs were reused over and over. The music isn't award winning by any means and to me didn't really stand out at all. Graphically the game is good by current standards and is something that you will admire at times but not necessary be left in awe over.

Gun fighting and the actual FPS aspect to the game is done perfect and never left me feeling like I didn't know what I was doing from a mechanic point of view. The dueling mechanic is fun and original, but is somewhat confusing at times. Expect some redoes if you plan on being honorable about your dueling. The singple player gameplay  was enjoyable with the exceptions of some instances where I felt like I was getting shot by an unknown assailant. I also felt that the skill trees although interesting, felt like a waste after you got the reloading skill points.  Arcade mode is interesting until you 3 star it and then it’s basically just playing the same levels over again minus story and an added few extra NPCs to kill, unless of course you enjoy ladders.

I really enjoyed myself from both an emersion standpoint and a mindless killing game. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good FPS single player with some extra content like arcade mode and new game plus.

+ Great gunfights
+ Funny NPC conversations
+ Good Visuals
- Gimmicky Duels
- Vanilla Levels
- Boring Arcade Mode

Score: 8 out of 10

reviewText: I can recommend this game since it offers very fun gameplay, if you like simple shooters.  The main character narrates the story through the whole game while you're playing, which is very atmospheric. The engine/graphics/artstyle are also nice to look at. The enemies and boss fights arent that much of a challenge (no tactics required). The combat itself is also simple (point, shoot, point, shoot...), but also offers variety by adding short, not too intrusive quicktime events, bullet time, etc... It's just fun taking enemies down that way :-) Playtime is about 3,5 hours for the story mode without looking for all the hidden items and trying to get achievements.

reviewText:
If you are looking for a Wild West shooter,you found one heck of a good one!
The Story is amazing. I love the idea that you are playing a Story being told by an old man... I mean come on you gotta love that :3
The Guns all feel great to use, aiming may be hard but after a time its easy to handle. It also feels awesome to knock sbd out with your fists, which isnt a common thing in Shooters! (*Cough* Cod-Knife *Cough*) The only weapon that kinda disappointed me was the Shotgun. Hardly and Range and not always a 1-Shot,and thats why you end up dieing most of the time you try to shoot with it.
The HP Regeneration is ok,you dont have to sit in cover for hours and wait till your screen stops bleeding. Its also a good idea that,when you die, you get a last chance and dodge the Deadly bullet.
The Graphics have a awesome comic style that you just have to fall in love with!The western scenery was just done so well!

So,in the end  even if you arent a big Western fan this game is definitely worth a try. I mean its just 15 Bucks for that Masterpiece!!!
And if my review didnt really convince you,try it out for yourself. The Demo is convincing enough!

reviewText:
A modern, carnival shooting gallery with some smart design choices and an amusing story.

Coming off of previous Call of Juarez installments I was not heading into Gunslinger with high hopes but I was pleasantly surprised and thoroughly enjoyed my brief time with it.
It’s presented very well, and its the presentation that steals the show. It has a strong, interesting narrative thats delivered by the protagonist, changing what’s happening in the game as he recalls it. Something we’ve seen in games before (think Bastion) and something thats done very well here.
The gameplay is a very “arcady” first-person-shooter, that’s well tuned with quick,responsive, controls. Just when you grow tired of the gameplay, the story wraps up - with a few twists and turns for good measure - and the game ends.

A short and sweet arcade shooter to add to your ever growing steam library.

reviewText:
Gunslinger's unreliable narrator is hilarious. I can praise the game's fantastic visuals and sound, or its visceral, intense gunplay...but really, my favorite part of this game is Silas Greaves' retelling of his literally unbelievable exploits alongside (and against) some of the Wild West's most notorious outlaws.

It's excellently voiced (by VA John Cygan, who even sings an impressive verse or two later in the game), and the narration itself often modifies the environment and the scenarios you encounter in real time. Mechanics aside, the tall tales are genuinely funny, especially when you see the bullsh*t coming a mile away.

In fact, I'll say it: This game implements narration better than Bastion. Give it a try and  tell me if you agree.

reviewText:
The Call of Juarez  franchise started out as a first person Wild West shooter and the first two games were much appreciated by the fans. With the third game, The Cartel, Ubisoft most likely pushed Techland to develop a modern-day version of the game to appeal to a wider audience. Suffice to say, The Cartel got torn into pieces both by fans and the press because of its shortcomings in regards to visuals, story, character design, AI and, of course, because they dumped the entire Wild West theme in favor of a Drug Cartel War theme taking place in the modern-day Los Angeles.

With Gunslinger, Techland finally went back to the roots of the franchise and provided fans of the series with some more smoking Revolvers and Wild West action.

The story is fairly simple and as Wild West cliché as it can get: You end up in a saloon and tell the story of how an outlaw killed your brothers, so you became a bounty hunter seeking for revenge and came across many other famous outlaws such as Billy the Kid, Butch Cassidy, Sundance Kid or the Dalton - who all stood in the way between you and your Nemesis.

While the story isn't exactly innovative, the storytelling itself definitely makes up for it as it is told in voice-over manner and makes up for some funny dialogues and actual game changing effects when the remaining crowd in the saloon questions details of the story. For example, 'you' tell them about how you've fought a hundred Indians all by yourself. The barkeeper thinks you're lying and couldn't have survived this, so the majority of Indians disappear from the level so that only a handful is left and then you reply something like 'Yeah, well, maybe it was a couple less...'. I can't recall I've seen a narration like this in another game, but I definitely liked it a lot.

The game is based on Techland's own Chrome Engine 5, which was also used for The Cartel and both Dead Island games, and makes use of a mix of both realistic and Cel-shaded graphics. While Gunslinger does look fairly decent on max settings, the lack of any AA option whatsoever makes for some really ugly jaggies around the edges of pretty much everything, so unless you force AA on in your graphics drivers or through a 3rd-party tool such as SweetFX, you will have to live with that.

Being a first person shooter, there aren't any surprises in regards to controls or movement. Everything feels smoth and precise and the hit feedback is also pretty satisfying, so you always know if you've hit an enemy with any of the, unfortunately, few weapons in the game - among them revolvers, a rifle, a shotgun and their sawn-off counterparts. Additionally, by killing enemies and racking up combos or by finding collectibles, you earn XP which you can spend on a variety of character upgrades.

My biggest gripe with the game, though, is the linearity. While the first two games basically had on open world where you could saddle your horse and just roam around, Gunslinger has a relatively narrow level design where a horse wouldn't even make sense, so they removed the horse riding aspect entirely from the game, which is a huge shame IMO.

With around 4.5 hours for the main story on normal difficulty, the game is fairly short but if you want to spend more time with it you can replay the story in the New Game+ mode, which will preserve all your previously unlocked upgrades and provide for some additional challenge. On top of that there is an Arcade mode with 10 levels where you can fight your way to the top of the leaderboards. Lastly, there is a Duel mode where you have 5 lives and  face 15 enemies one after another until you either win or run out of lives.

Call of Juarez: Gunslinger has some minor flaws, but for a budget game like this I'm extremely surprised by its quality, so if you're a fan of the original CoJ games or just want a decent Wild West experience, give Gunslinger a shot (heh) and check the game's store page for the Demo download button.

reviewText:
To tell you the truth I never thought this would be my favourite Call of Juarez game of all the 4 titles available. Well, if you look at the western-themed games there are just 3 out there - we can disregard The Cartel which is set in modern day Los Angeles for the sake of this review.

What I like about the game is that it does not take itself seriously. Silas, our protagonist, goes to a saloon and starts the telling of many tales with the involvement of all the legendary Wild West outlaws. Silas either killed, wounded these people or just rode alongside them. Every level is a different tale with a different setting and outlaw.

Now, about the gameplay: slow-mo is more frequent than in previous games and duelling is easier and more exciting. You have more collectibles hidden throughout each level and these so-called nuggets" fill the in-game database with a lot of information on the era: everything you wanted to know about every outlaw
hoursPlayed: etc.\n\nKilling people with precision and speed allows you to obtain more experience points - levelling up lets you pick a skill / upgrade which aims to take you to the land of specialisation. You'll be an expert of weapon handling so you are free to pick which weapon will be the most suitable for you. With the shotgun you can be the master of close-quarter combat
voteText: with the rifle you can further enhance your precision aiming and become the ultimate sharpshooter and with the dual-wielding of pistols you can really become a true cowboy.\n\nLevels can be played separately

after finishing the story just for the sake of obtaining more scores to compete with your friends on leaderboards. The same goes for duels - one duel after another during which you have a limited number of lives: Do you have what it takes to win all of them without reloading?

Techland's Chrome Engine offers us more colourful visuals than ever. The game has vivid colours and overall you can see more attention was put into detail than in any previous CoJ game. Not only does it look good but it runs at a smooth 60 FPS.

This has been the best CoJ game to date. The story is forgettable but let's be honest we only play a western-themed game for its shootouts and Gunslinger has just claimed the throne."

reviewText:
It doesn't take long for Gunslinger to reveal its true hand: though not the most well-financed shooter doing the rounds, a distinctive narrative approach helps it stand out from the crowd of same olds.

Competent enough as genre fodder, Wild West-era Gunslinger isn't just about shootouts and sawn-offs: Silas Greaves, fastest gun that no-one ever heard of, is your unreliable and increasingly inebriated narrator through this story of blood and dust.

Stylishly presented, crammed full of period locations and a dirty dozen's worth of well-known renegades, Gunslinger's cheeky storytelling is matched well against stunning vistas and plenty of outlaw confrontations.

Sure, Gunslinger has its limitations. But an arcade mode and limited-lives dueling challenge provide a shot of friendly competition as diversion from the game's main draw, and at eight to ten hours long, it's satisfying enough as a single-player experience if you're willing to go along for the ride and see where it takes you.

reviewText:
IntroThis game is a absolute fun masterpiece that'll have you laughing and really get you caught into the game for many hours to come, so I'm going to do some Pros and Cons on why you should buy this game, but like everything else it does still have some issues

Pros- Great Campaign - this is an extremely fun campaign with a great amount of hours to play, its mostly a cartoonish first person shooter that goes through the stories/tall tales of Silas Grieves as you take out some of the baddest guys of the west, now one of the funniest parts about this is that during the game it'll be narrated by yourself(or Silas Grieves) and sometimes as he speaks he'll say oh wait I wasn't fighting Apache Indians, bandits were fighting me Apache style and then the enemies change during gameplay, it's really funny
- Level Design - each level in the game is extremely unique and fun to explore, it's also well balanced with enemies and interactable objects, though I have gotten lost a few times in some places but its usually pretty easy to find out where your suppose to go
- Gameplay - the gameplay for this game is great as it is with most first person shooters, with numerous weapons to use and a great skill tree that allows you to upgrade your character and skills with weapons and other things and if you upgrade almost everything in a specific tree then you get a special golden gun the corresponds with the tree that you leveled up
- Runs Smoothly - During my entire play time in this game I've never had a single crash, lag, or FPS drop, the game runs absolutely perfectly
- Standoffs - this is one of my overall favorite parts of the game is standoffs, when ever you get to a bad guy or main villain in the story you'll have a standoff of or some type of gunner battle, and a few unique ones, but standoffs are like they are in the movies two people staring each other down and then making a quick draw to shoot him down honorably, it can be hard at times but it really makes you feel like your in the west especially the huge one at the end
- NO UPLAY - for once and only once Ubisoft actually made a game that doesn't require you to login in with your Uplay account before you play, and I really do like that though I would still like to get the Uplay points from the game I'd rather get steam achievements

Cons- Not Enough Replay Value - though the campaign does have some replay value with the golden nuggets and such, and there is a timed game mode to get the best score there's just not enough to really give you more that 15 hours so it ends up being a short play
- No Multiplayer - for a game that could so easily have it but yet its not there, I would really have loved to see this game with a multiplayer feature, and the fact that its not in here feels kinda lazy
- More Features Or Modes - even though this is a great game it needs a lot more to keep you in the moment and offer a lot more replay value

Final VerdictI'd definitely make sure to buy this game but especially if it's on sale for like $2 which is what I payed and as I can see a complete steal, but as a overall score I'd have to give this game a 6/10 purely because of the fact that even though it's great it comes off a quick play and needs a lot more replay value and could have used more features to give the game uniqueness, any that's all for my review so if you haven't already go make sure to go get this game for a quick play and the laughs!!!

reviewText:
A little gem I was expecting to be this enjoyable, I am by no means a good FPS player and wanted something to just jump into quickly have a short bash then back to normal life. This Wild West show bowled me over and here are a few of the reasons…

Excellent Voice-acting, nice visuals and terrain with brilliant maps (although I noticed one was a reuse, may have been more not sure). Excellent music with a real Wild West theme. The narration does well to keep the campaign play through engaging, and doesn't take itself too seriously and this deserves a special mention as it was spot on (some of the lines made me chuckle and the story telling was brill). Nice historical bits of history that are enjoyable to read through collectables. Solid, entertaining gunplay mechanics. Nice upgrade trees all fairly unique depending on play style. Frequent checkpoints, useful for someone who dies (A LOT) and is pants at FPS. Extra features such as mini game duel (which I loved!), and arcade game.

I could mention the negatives but I would just be picking this game is well worth it even more so when on sale, thumbs up from me!

reviewText:
It's a generic FPS with a wild western flair.
But, partner, the narrative!

PROS:

+ exceptional narrative and voice acting
+ chill and kill
+ duels and standoffs

CONS:

- a bit short
- lacks depth gameplaywise

I expected nothing when launching Call of Juarez: Gunslinger.
The game ambushed me with a truly amazing and unusual storytelling approach.
Drinking spirits while playing is highly recommended.
You're playing out stories told by Silas Greaves, a seasoned bounty hunter.
The gameplay doesn't offer anything trailblazing- your arsenal is quite limited, there are three skill trees you can make use of when levelling up, some QTEs here and there, plenty of slow-mo.
There are boss fights" in the form of cinematic western duels in which you have to control your gun drawing hand and the aim; a nice touch.
The main strength of Gunslinger is the way the stories of Silas are told.
A golden nugget
recommended: Death..won't you spare me over another year.."\n"

reviewText: I can’t stress enough how much I recommend playing this game to anyone interested in western-style games. It is a very well made game, with a very interesting (and pretty unique in some ways) story helped a lot by its good graphics and astonishing sound design, which fit the game perfectly. The performance across the whole game was very good, with no graphical glitches or FPS drops. Absolutely a must-play for those interested in western games, and why not, for those interested in a good FPS shooter! Too bad there aren’t other western games this good to choose from…

reviewText:
It doesn't need Uplay? Yes!

Fine, bought.

---

Call of Juarez Gunslinger is a very linear arcade shooter, but in a good way. It's fun. I just paid ~3€ via summer sale and it was worth the money. ;)

The story mode is finished after 4-5 hours, which is okay... because it's not a full price titel and never was as far as i know. And you can do face-offs and an arcade mode with leatherboard besides story mode.

The gameplay is very basic but super smooth.

The graphics are really good if you enable AA with a 3rd party programm. As a Nvidia user i used Nvidia Inspector.

Sound could be a bit better, but it's OK.

7.5/10 - recommendable for a low price

reviewText: This game is an absolute blast. It has a distinct arcade-like style to it, with over-the-top action, rewards for being flashy, and so forth. Anyone who played old light-gun games in the arcades can get a kick out of this one. Aside from that, the story is surprisingly interesting, and told in a really interesting and often funny way. The game has a surprising amount of depth, and lots of great little design choices like how if you blaze through a level without too much trouble, the game will offer to up the difficulty automatically. And it perfectly captures the old romanticized version of the good old Wild West. If you like shooter games or the old west, definitely pick this one up.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
TL;DR: Short and sweet, a fast paced action packed western FPS, with a nice art style and a well told story.

Call of Juarez Gunslinger is a little gem of a game. With the western setting you will adventure through the recollections of Silas Greaves. The world has a very attractive cell shaded look and mixed with comic strip styled cut scenes gives the game a beautiful tone. Using a set of iconic weapons to dispatch your enemies in an arcade shooter. The story is told in a fun and interesting way with environments changing with the story as it is being told. With upgrade paths and solid mechanics such as bullet time and one on one duels the small package fits in a lot of gameplay.

Positive features:
-Good stylised graphics
-Fast paced arcade shooter with varying weapons
-Fantastic soundtrack
-Funny and interesting story
-Collectibles that add real backstory to the game
-Very well optimised

Negative features:
-Confusing navigation at times
-Difficulty seeing enemies in certain areas

To conclude Call of Juarez Gunslinger is a satisfying game which doesn't overstay its welcome, fun to play through more than once with other reasons to return to it. A well told story and a well-made game.

reviewText: 8/10\n\nTake on legendary outlaws of the Wild West, including Billy the Kid and Jesse James
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Lately I've been asking myself if it's possible that I'm just done shooting a man. I constantly find myself bored with FPS games; generally, if I finish one it's just because I was determined to see it through to the end despite the whole thing where I'm not actually having fun. About an hour into Gunslinger, I exited the game, convinced that this was actually the case. I was done with FPSes. Time to hang up my disembodied guns.

Then I loaded up this game again, mostly because I love the story conceit of this game so I wanted to see it through to the end (plus I heard it was pretty short so what the hell). Woops I was real ♥♥♥♥in' wrong. My bad. I slogged on for a bit longer, then I started getting deeper into the skill trees. Then the game finally became what it was supposed to be. I guess my impatience is showing if I feel that a game takes too long to get going after an hour, but here we are. Once you gain skills that start improving your ability to combo, the game arrives where it should have been at the beginning.

If you're feeling tl;dr, skip the next two paragraphs. They're pretty spergy. Then come back (or don't).

I made the mistake of starting with the shotgun and rifle skill trees. Who would have thought that in a game called GUNSLINGER, maybe the GUNSLINGER tree was the way to go. Imagine that. So you make your way down the gunslinger tree, your combos last longer, do bonus damage, whatever. Then you reach the last skill (this will take you like an hour if you go right for it.) It refills your concentration (bullet time) meter every time your combo reaches a multiple of 6. Holy ♥♥♥♥, now this is a game. You're now chaining entire multiple wave setpieces down without your opponents getting to take a shot. Maybe there's just a part of me that loves the mental image of loads of guys exploding into blood decals the second they peek their heads out from behind a wall all at once. It's incredible.

I know this is a hyperspecific way to play the game, and one size probably doesn't fit all, so I'll just go on to say that the game is probably still fun even if this doesn't tickle your fancy the way it does for me. I should probably tell you that the other skill trees are also well thought out and give you fun additional things that change the way the game plays. In the close quarters tree you gain the ability to throw back dynamite off the ground (maybe this should have been free), make your dynamite split into individual sticks in midair (with predictable results), and even skip reloading in concentration mode (this is a game changer, considering shotguns are two shot affairs). I felt like they were pretty weak until I got a couple damage boosts, but then after that all close quarters levels were handled with akimbo sawed-offs. The rifle tree is less exciting, but the rifle is already stupid overpowered so I guess that's ok. I mostly just used the pistol skills with a rifle.

----

Now that that's over... the story in this game is pretty great. You're an old bounty hunter sitting at a bar with some strangers,  telling tall tales about how you were friends with, had run ins with, or killed pretty much every single outlaw that pop culture has deemed worthy of keeping in the public conscience. You begin your first mission with Billy the Kid, end up chasing Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, and eventually winging Jesse James. The thing that I love about this game though is the way the narrative sometimes changes midsentence. You'll play a sequence, then your narrator will inform you that that didn't actually happen, and then a totally different story will play out. I know that probably reads like lazy storytelling but it's really well done, in my opinion. Paths will open up in front of you when the story deems it necessary even though there was nothing there before. I lost my ♥♥♥♥ when I saw my first sky ladder.

So um, the bad. The duels are an excellent concept, but in practice can be super frustrating! I played with a controller and I feel like the analog sticks helped tremendously, so maybe that's something to consider. I actually tried doing a duel with mouse and keyboard before I wrote this and I can't say I recommend it. It's kind of a generic shooter until you get down the skill trees, but this probably isn't as big of a knock for most people as it is for me. The game is about 4 hours long. I'm not really a dollar per hour kind of guy but I can see this mattering for some people so I think it's worth mentioning. I think it has pretty good replay value but I'm the type of person that plays a game 2 or 3 times most of the time anyway.

Go buy this game. I want more old west shooters. Thanks.

(I also want to add that I think it's really funny comparing the hyper stylized comic book panels for all the main characters to the actual pictures of the dumpy looking dudes that you can find on the game's collectibles. At least wear a cowboy hat, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.)

reviewText:
This is a rather short and linear game, but I love the way the story is told. Similar in a way to Bastion where the main character (you) narrates the sometimes over exaggerated western story in the late 1800's early 1900's. The landscape changes as it is being told, enemies appear and sometimes (hundreds out of thin air) When one of the listeners found themselves falling asleep during a fairly dull part of the game. Overall the humour is fantastic and it's well-paced game.


The gun-play is arcadey, Gun choices are fairly limited. You're giving a small variety of revolvers, shotguns and bolt action rifles. There is a small skill-tree and a leveling system in the game. You'll have special abilities that can help you dodge bullets in slow motion, as well as pulling off multi-kills during that slow motion duration.


Call of Juarez Gunslinger is a GOOD looking game. The cell-shaded art is beautiful and the scenery is gorgeous. As I was playing many times I was just floored by the incredible scene that lay in front of me.  There's a good amount of content in this game. You get the story mode (which has 2 endings) with a new game+ mode. An Arcade mode for high scores and Duels where you just face off against NPC's in an old western style duel! If you're a fan of westerns, or just fast-paced FPS then this would be worth your time.


*I should add that Uplay is NOT required to run this game!

reviewText:
Call of Juarez: Gunslinger has an old-west whiskey soaked narrative that rises above its arcade style FPS shooting and absolutely steals the show.

My good buddy, fellow The F Plus podcast participant, and United Gaming Clans TF2 superstar Frank West was kind enough to buy a copy of this game for me in exchange for a review, and how could I say no to that face? (By the way: Visit thefpl.us for horrifying things read with enthusiasm. No, I don't care about ethics in gaming journalism.)

So when I booted up Call of Juarez: Gunslinger for the first time, I noticed two things:

1: Oh, hey, the protagonist is narrating his story as I am shooting the bad guys.
2: Hold up, wait a minute. Techland made this? Dead Island Techland?

Yep, the same guys who made Dead Island made this. And I'm pretty surprised with how it turned out, given that Techland is known lately for making ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (like Dead Island, Dead Island: Riptide, Escape Dead Island), and the sequel that nearly killed this franchise dead: Call of Juarez The Cartel. Despite The Cartel being a pile of garbage with a cowboy hat on the top, Call of Juarez lived to fight another day, and I'm so glad it did because it resulted in Gunslinger. (It's not without its share of dumb visual design decisions, such as the quick-time bullet event happening when you've shot a cowboy to death and another dude shoots a killing shot that passes through his body and only appears through the other side when it's too ♥♥♥♥ing late to decide when to dodge. Or that entire level where you're fighting underneath a railroad bridge, where the shadows and the daylight contrast into this visually horrid mess that made my eyes cross.)

All the FPS elements here are solid, but what makes the game really stand out is that Silas Greaves (the dude you're playing as) is telling the story of his blood-soaked career as a bounty hunter. The entire game is framed through Silas's recollection and storytelling as he's sitting there, getting loaded in a bar while skeptics and dime-store novel junkies hang on his every word and call his story out at points. For a moment, one of the people listening to his story says that the Pinkertons were fighting the same train robbers as he was, and the Pinkertons arrive to help Silas. But then, he says I've been there

reviewText:
Někdo je tu skvělej Ganslinga eheheh. Call of Juarez Gunslinger je takové Call of Duty (náhodná shoda jmen?) ve westernovém prostředí. Bezproblémově si zastřílíte v různorodých prostředích, proti různým nepřátelům s různými zbraněmi a poměrně humorně podaným příběhem. Příběh se totiž celý točí kolem Silase Greavese který přišel do salonu vyprávět své dobrodružství a vy ta dobrodružství hrajete. Hra má pěknej humor, atmosféru a svižně se hraje. Duely jsou dynamické a ačkoliv je Gunslinger plný quick-time eventů, mě vyjímečně tady dost bavili. Takové to uhýbání kulkám v matrix čase, či výskok a postřílení všech nepřátel okolo six-shootery. Je to zábava a zároveň se to vypráví a vypadá krásně.

reviewText:
This game is quite good and is lots of fun!

Gameplay- The controls are great as the character is easily maneuverable
- It's fast-paced action with hardly any slow gameplay
- A nice abilities tree to work with, and it is possible to get every single ability
- Has a nice playtime of about 10-15 hours, along with the other modes that will add extra time
- Captures the western times well

Combat- Fast paced, however by the end it gets a little easy as you become overpowered. This effect can be negated if you put the game on the hardest difficulty at the start. Although you may struggle, by the end it will be a satisfying playhtrough!
- There are duels at the end of almost every single level, adn unfortunately i found they  get a little repetitive after a while

Graphics- For those that are put off by the black border and the field of view don't worry because it is easily removable
- Has the black outline around objects making it quite similar to the Borderlands series

Story- Has a fairly basic story but enough to keep you interested

OverallFor the price that this game is asking for, it is definitely worth picking up as it is a solid game and will fill up a weekend easily :)

reviewText:
No idea how this game wasn't on my radar sooner. Checked it out due to a friend's recommendation and was blown away. The writing/voice acting/narrative is top notch and the shooting mechanics thoroughly engaging.

Prior to playing this entry in the Call of Juarez series, I did play through the original and Bound in Blood, and I will say that there is no connection between them and this game, so you don't have to go back through the whole series to enjoy this one. Which, depending on your patience, is probably for the best.

Beautiful looking game, fun Wild West shooting action, and a thoroughly entertaining alternative history telling of some major elements of American history.

Highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys shooters at all.

When it comes to narration, Bastion did it better.

reviewText:
Having a lot of fun with this one (just finished True West mode and started Arcade). It goes very cheap on sales, so if you like western shooters - go grab it!

The game has style - from the cool hand-drawn cutscenes, through badass character design, to hilarious and twisted narration. Twisted? The story is presented by an old bounty hunter sitting in a bar and entertaining some locals, but since he's speaking about famous characters and events - he often gets interrupted. We can hear the conversations in the bar during the missions and the events change in real-time as the narrator suddenly remembers something or gets corrected :D

The gunplay is very satisfying - guns pack a punch, you can go bullet-time, chain combos, dodge a deadly shot once in a while, you can unlock new skills and better weapons... did I mention it has duels and mexican stand-offs?

Story mode is about 5h and it feels just enough - you don't have a chance to get bored. Mastering Arcade (time-attack) and Duels modes will also take about 5h each.

Seriously, go grab it.

I recommend this game very much

reviewText: The story might be a bit cheesy, and the voice acting isn't amazingly great, but this is, at heart, still a solid first person shooter. After dabbling a bit in other, not as atmospherical settings (ie The Cartel), this game returns to the best game in the series, Bound in Blood, and puts us in that classic western mood. The mechanics are solid, no unnecessary gimmicks or items or stuff like that, just a few proper guns. There isn't great variety in them, but one can imagine there wasn't, back in that day. The story has a neat twist, in that it is narrated, and sometimes the narrator forgets" or "remembers" things
date: which in turn has an effect on the gameplay.\nThe story is short (7 hours)

reviewText:
This game is to spaghetti westerns what Max Payne is to film noir. Which is to say, brilliant.

The gunslinging itself is solidly enjoyable, but the real magic comes from the unreliable narrator telling the embellished, half-remembered tale you're playing through. It takes its cue from what Baston got right and runs from there, and the bleed between Silas sat in a saloon telling the tale and the tale being told is often hilarious and just a bit clever.

It's mechanically fun, it's narratively compelling, it's dripping with style, and it's funny. Play this game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Call of Juarez Gunslinger is a great western shooter. The storytelling was entertaining because it was told through flashbacks by the main character, who always had some funny remarks about the situations he was in.
The graphics were absolutely gorgeous on max settings.
The gameplay was really fun too. It played like a typical western shooter with guns like a shotgun, rifle and revolver, but it added some cool features like boss fights and bullet time. Skills like bullet time could be improved by the simple leveling system. Also very cool were the one-to-one duels, where you have to shoot your opponent before he shoots you (obviously), which will put your reaction time to the test.
My only complaint about this game is that it was too short ! I completed it in less than 5 hours. After that you can also play arcade mode and duels, but those are not as entertaining as the main story. You can also start a new game+ on a harder difficulty to make full use of the skills you got through the leveling system in the first playtrough, but that's about it.
I would recommend the game to anyone who even remotely likes shooters or westerns (or both), because of the fun gameplay, the gorgeous visuals and the entertaining storytelling.

reviewText:
Call of Juarez® Gunslinger Review

What is good about Call of Juarez?
- The game looks amazing, the art styles blends well with the western theme of the game
- Gun combat is really great.
- The got some extra modes like Arcade and Duel to keep you playing when you are done
- The story is good
- Voice acting is also great
- Duel combat is hard and fun

What is bad about Call of Juarez® Gunslinger?
- Most boss battels feel the same, not alot of variety of bosses
- The rifle is so overpowerd it probaly the only gun you need in the game.
- Alot of the enemies feel the same and look the same.¨

8/10 a must buy for any one that loves FPS games
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Before I start off:

- I ran the game on max settings without any mods
- I've played through the story on 'Hard' mode
- I have no experience with any of the other 'Call of Juarez' games

First off, the settings:

- Full set of resolutions, probably goes past 60Hz
- No AA or filtering options
- Just 'Low', 'Medium' and 'High' for texture quality, etc.
- Subtitles option :)
- You can change lots of audio volumes, but no '0-100%' indicator
- Detailed 'How to Play' menu
- Limited key bindings, an annoyance because of some odd buttons
- Detailed mouse options, smoothing, invert, etc.

---

Okay, so let's start with the game. The graphics aren't bad, but definitely not 2013 material. However, this isn't really an issue, as it still looks good enough in my eyes. I haven't played any of the other games, and as far as I saw you do not need to play any of them to understand any part of the story. You play as Silas Greaves, reliving his memories as a bounty hunter. A large portion of the game has narration between Silas as an older man, and some other characters in a bar. The narration is often comical and dosen't disrupt the game, so it's likeable. The game makes clear that it's about a man reliving his thoughts, because objects appear from nowhere, taking off any serious edge from the stereotypical 'Hollywood Western' style.

Throughout the entire game there's a really thick black layer around the edge of the entire screen. It's a bit cumbersome at first, but you get used to it. I have no idea why it's there. It's pointless. You can tell it was ported from the Xbox 360, because you can see the D-pad icon on the weapon wheel, but the game is still quite well optimised, as I've never had any drops in framerate throughout the entire game. Most of the controls - the important ones - work very well for KB+M, but some, for example the 'Show objective location' button is set to 'O' and cannot be rebound.

This game sets you against outlaws and more in every mission in the exact same way; they shoot and you shoot back. This is what all FPS games are like, and it puts lots of people off (those who prefer strategy or RPG games) because of it's simplicity. But as someone who is sick and tired of this same formula, I was very surprised. The gunplay is very easy to get used to, but will require some practice to master. It perfectly manages (on hard mode at least) to make you feel like the best gunslinger in the Wild West, while still giving you lots of room for failure. The UI is minimal and looks nice, and aside from the annoying border I mentioned earlier, fits in nicely. It has an arcade style scoring system, which puts up your mission score amongst your friends for some replayability.

You are doing the same thing on every single mission; killing people in the exact same way and fighting a 'boss' at the end. There are collectibles, but all of them have Wild West lore within and there's only roughly 3 per mission, so it's a nice amount that actually gives you a reason to find them, unlike in most Ubisoft games nowadays. But surprisingly, dual-wielding revolvers and taking down 5 enemies in 3 seconds never ceased being entertaining, aside from the duel minigame, which was interesting at first but it was compulsory and tedious, and happened at the end of most missions. There's 2 gamemodes aside from 'Story': 'Arcade' and 'Duels', but both are just recycled from the Story and are very boring and pointless if you've finished it. On the whole though, with a leveling system that isn't just plastic to one playthrough of the story, a new difficulty setting unlocked after one playthrough, and a New Game+ option, the game's replayability just isn't enough to warrant a second playthrough. It's a fun game, but because it relies on surprise QTEs and slow-mo showdowns that don't have the same effect on the second time through. For me, on hard mode it took merely almost 3 hours to play through what I think the game had to offer (The story, a tiny bit of arcade mode).

I thoroughly enjoyed this game, and it was a truly refreshing FPS experience. The biggest downside is the length of the story and lack of replayability, but for £11.99, I'd say it's worth it. It's also often on a discount so if you don't have much money, you won't have to wait long before you can buy it for less.

Thanks for reading.

date: I assumed it would be more of a shooting gallery than anything.  Ends up that this is probably one of the best story driven FPS games I've played in a while. I would say that the showdown mechanics are really annoying (precision mouse movements and key presses at the same time), but that's probably to keep the difficulty level high.\n\nAll in all, a great game. reviewText:
This is overall one of the better western games I have played and has a good upgrading system, great physics, somewhat destroyable environment and good firefighting.

BUT, the one thing I didn't like about this game was the guns, the guns in this game are EXCELLENT to use and high detail but as the game moves foward in time, I felt like I was missing out on all the new weaponary of the time, like in the year 1910 for example people still used all the old guns in real life but there were tons of new ones peope used as well and I have listed some that should have been there or can maybe be there for the next game(you should look them up):

Bolt Action Rifes:

-M1903 Springfield from 1900 onwards (not realistic but almost all the guns are anachronistic)
-M1892 Krag Jorgensen Rifle from 1890 onwards

Semi Automatic Pistols

-Mauser C96 from 1895 onwards (not realistic but almost all the guns are anachronistic, besides the gun 1896 one year later)
-Colt M1900/M1902 from 1900 (1902 model is almost identical)

Double Action Revolvers

-Colt M1877 from 1877 onwards besides John Wesley Hardin used this gun
-Colt 1892 .38 Revolver

Yeah thats it I give this game 8.9/10 if the next game gets these guns and mabye a bit of open worldish feel like the older ones then ill give it 12/10

reviewText: This game makes me wish there were more set in the old west. There isn't much bad to say about this game, it's got a great art style, perfect tone and a storyline full of tense moments along with it's fair share of humor. I want to spend more time in the environment the developers have created.\n\nThe first great western video game I have played since GUN back in '05. reviewText: Call of Juarez Gunslinger takes you back to old spaghetti westerns and dime novel stories when justice was often found at the end of a barrell.  After his brothers are murdered Silas Greaves sets out on a war path of vengeance chasing down some of the most iconic criminals, horse thieves and murderers of the 1800's.  This game is a great FPS shooter with great storytelling, solid fluid controls and dueling.  At full price this game is a steal but at a discount you would be doing yourself a great disservice not to play it.   The question you need to ask yourself is do you seek revenge or redemption?

-Colt M1900/M1902 from 1900 (1902 model is almost identical)

Double Action Revolvers

-Colt M1877 from 1877 onwards besides John Wesley Hardin used this gun
-Colt 1892 .38 Revolver

Yeah thats it I give this game 8.9/10 if the next game gets these guns and mabye a bit of open worldish feel like the older ones then ill give it 12/10

reviewText: This game makes me wish there were more set in the old west. There isn't much bad to say about this game, it's got a great art style, perfect tone and a storyline full of tense moments along with it's fair share of humor. The story mode isn't terribly long, clocking in just at 5 hours for my first playthrough. The game makes up for this with a new game+, arcade mode, leaderboards and duels mode. So you can still easily sink a good amount of time into it if you're so inclined, I know I will. I want to spend more time in the environment the developers have created.\n\nThe first great western video game I have played since GUN back in '05. I dare say I enjoyed this game more than that, granted this is more linear than GUN was. I won't  hesistate to recommend this to anyone who is a fan of the western genre.

reviewText: call of juarez hasnt been a series that i have followed but i was highly interested in this game after the very positive reviews and the steam sale. straight to the point this game is fantastic and if your a fan of the series or likes western shooters then this is the game for you. it took me only 7 hours to complete my first playthrough but it was the highest quality 7 hours i have played in a while. the gun play is addictive and the level design is perfect. the story revolves around a bounty hunter silas greaves who is telling his adventurous stories to get free drinks. this leads to some comical and sometimes hilarious diologue over the exciting gameplay. deffinitly worth the price for what you are getting. highley reccomended.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Gunslinger is by far the best game in the CoJ franchise. If you want a wildly entertaining single player FPS set in the old west, this is the game for you. You're a retired bounty hunter in a saloon where people buy you drinks to hear your stories. The further into the game you go, the more drinks you've had, so the stories get more exaggerated. When bar patrons catch you in a lie, the level quickly changes as you try to adapt your story. It's pretty hilarious. The cell shaded graphics look great. The skill trees in both Story and Arcade mode really change the way you play. I got through Story mode on easy difficulty in about 10 hours, and have since been replaying on a harder difficulty as well as spending time in Arcade mode. There are more environmental traps to watch out for on the harder difficulty settings, such as mining carts flying through tunnels which will kill you if you don't get out of the way in time.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Rating: 9/10
Overview: First Person Shooter

The Good:

+ Every level has its own distinct environment and atmosphere. The developers did a great job bringing the western atmosphere to life

+ Shooting mechanics feel great, every weapon has its own weight and feel to them.

+  A great narrative with fantastic voice acting. You are not required to play the previous two games as this is a standalone story. The narrative/story really carries the game giving the game a nice pace so that things never feel truly repetitive, one of my smaller complaints from the previous game.

+ Killing enemies grants experience allowing you to upgrade among three different skill trees.

+ Arcade mode allows you to replay certain sections of the single player trying to attain a high score killing as many enemies as fast as possible

+ Duel mode allows you to duel back to back with 5 lives.

+ New Game + carries over all you experience and collectables

+ Soundtrack

The Average:

The game crashed a lot upon exiting to desktop

Conclusion:

I went into the Call of Juarez series knowing nothing and I am surprised in how much I like it throughout the series. The games just keep getting better and better. A very fun first person shooter.

reviewText:
Very good Singleplayer-FPS, one of the few that actually catched me in the last years.

Nice Gunplay with good feedback and still decent graphics. Weapon variety could be higher, but not a big problem imo.

Best thing is the extremely good storytelling of an actually interesting wildwest-story.

AI is nothing special but not bad either.

Worst thing are the duels imho, they seem pretty random in their outcome and usually need multiple tries to get through.
Since they dont happen all too often and are still pretty tense i dont consider this to be a big problem though.

Overall one of the best singleplayer-FPS i have played in recent times. Definitely worth checking out.

reviewText:
Highly recommended, albeit short title.  It's hard to have a compelling story in a single player shooter, but Gunslinger gets it right with its interesting narration throughout, as told to a bunch of bar patrons.  As the star gets called out on overembellishment or recalls missing pieces, the game changes with it; paths open up, the weather changes, or even entire sections are replayed.  The campaign is short (took around 4 hours on hard), but it is a perfect length I think for a story like this and it doesn't overstay its welcome.

The shooting is also solid and while there isn't a whole lot of weapon variety, the pieces provided do make you feel like a gun slinger.  A few iterations of bullet time round out this western; nothing cooler than making a split second reflex button press and dodging an otherwise fatal round.

Worth a look if you've got a few hours to kill (the game also has speedrun/leaderboard items to add to longevity).
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Colorful, inventive and stylish, Gunslinger is a valuable edition to the Call of Juarez series. It has very realistic and imaginative level design. The in-game physics are very believable, as they reproduce very realistic effects. The dialogu and the accent of the narrator is highly entertaining and authentic. Whilst there could have been more period specific weapons, such as the 1887 Shotgun and the 1895 Winchester, the existing ones are pleasing to both the eye and are a joy to shoot. Gunslinger is more a visual perfection of the series, which attempts to add the graphic novel element to dramatic effect and succeeds. The reloading animation of the Winchester and the shortended Winchester are wrong and the Schofield is too quick, but the weapons otherwise work well and the powder barrel explosions are both effective and impressive to watch. Fans of the series and western afficionados will find a lot of things to like about this game.

reviewText:
One word.

♥♥♥♥INGAWESOME.

Yes, that's one word.

Simply put, this game calls upon the spirit of the western.  The Good, The Bad, & The Ugly, Pale Rider, A Fistfull of Dollars, and even the genre bookend Unforgiven, are what this game emulates and channels perfectly.

I am simply shocked that I haven't played this game until now, and even feel a little guilty for not having paid full price for this on release day.

Despite the romanticism of the storytelling, I also enjoyed the Nuggets of Truth metagame (well not so much the finding secrets as the factual tidbits of history contained in each nugget) that added the historical flavour of the backdrop.

Even the multi-perspective story pacing was an enjoyable play element, which was always wonderfully used to guide the player along the on-rails story, making you rarely (if ever) disappointed with the linear nature of the game, but rather makes you appreciate that this is a story being told.

If you even have a passing appreciation for the western genre, you owe it to yourself to play this game.  And if you don't, what the ♥♥♥♥ is wrong with you?  Make yourself less broken by buying and playing this game.

reviewText:
I don't really write reviews, but I'll be damned if I don't write one for this masterpiece. It may be short, but it sure is sweet. With the perfect balance of Borderlands-esque humor and art style, mixed with the sheer beauty of the west, it's one of the most enjoyable games that I have ever played. The combat is tight and frantic, with extremely satisfying gunshots and explosions.

You'll meet a ensemble of many legends of the Wild West on your journey, and you'll kill most of them. Though Silas' story may be a bit exaggerated, you will discover nuggets of truth" along the way. These nuggets are little snippets of the true history of the West and it's outlaws.

While a part of me wishes that it was much longer
date: I think the shortness of the game is actually one of it's strengths. It doesn't outstay its welcome - it doesn't lose its focus
hoursPlayed: along the way. From start to finish
helpfulPercent: with great combat

reviewText:
A very fun and creative game that has interesting storytelling elemenst similar to the Borderlands 2 DLC: Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep, but set in a western environment. The story mode can be quite quick, especially if you're acquainted with other FPS games and play at the easiest difficulty, but is supplimented by collectibles you can go back and search for in each level, 3 difficulty levels, an arcade mode where you can attempt to get the highest score, a duel gauntlet, and a NG+ mode.

Skills in this game actually feel rewarding and like they impact the gameplay, making the decision about which to get take some preplanning and consideration. The rifle, shotgun, and pistols all play differently and allow freedom on what playstyle you want, but the upgraded versions you get from skills feel only marginally unique and do little to differ from one another, except visually.

The visuals were appealing to me, not ultra-realistic but went in line with the storytelling and recollection elements of the game. Felt very satisfying to shoot something or for an explosion to go off, or to see bullets going by as you slowed time down and sprayed into a room. It is an old game, but that doesn't get in the way of playing it (except alt-tabbing, don't do that unless you intend on closing the game).

Honestly, the only downside would be the amount of hours you could put into this before having 'done' everything. To complete the story mode twice, 3 star all the arcade levels, and collect about half of the collectibles, took me about 15-20 hours (5-10 offline). However, this game is on sale often and can be found lower than the $9.99 pricepoint. But this game was definitely worth the time and money I put into it, and deserves to get a lot more recognition than it has so far.

EDIT: THIS GAME IS ACTUALLY A 2013 GAME, MY MISTAKE.
