reviewText:
The 2011 release 'CoJ:The Cartel' received lots of criticism.
Did Techland take notice and is this game any better?
In short: hell yeah!


*** THE STORY ***

It's the 19th century - The Wild West.
You take on the role of Silas Greaves. A bounty hunter.
The story is told by Silas himself (in exchange for some free whiskey) as he reflects on his journey.

Silas is on a quest for revenge. To right a wrong done to him. Hunting his archnemesis all throughout 'The Wild West' and meeting some notorious outlaws in the process. 'Billy: The Kid', 'Jesse James' and 'Butch Cassidy' to name a few. You'll actually get to duel them in a typical mexican standoff, but more on that later. In pursuit of your archnemesis, you''ll come across bank heists, train robberies, and what would a western be without some indians trying to scalp you.

Overall it's a pretty decent story. Nothing new, we all heard it before. Some plot twists and turns, but it's well executed. The voice acting is quite solid and the narrative style of storytelling contributes to the atmosphere of the game. I also liked the occasional story rewind of how things really went down. It seems our dear Mr. Silas Greaves tends to exaggerate a bit. Let's just contribute that to all the free whiskey he's been pouring down his throat in exchange for this story.


*** GRAPHICS ***

Graphics are great. It's a cel shaded style, which really fits the setting in this case. Some features include sun shafts, water ripples, weather effects and destructible objects. You have the ocassional low resolution textures, but nothing really disturbing. I'm usually to busy shooting people in the face anyways. Overall it looks really stunning and runs quite smooth also. I tend to favor gameplay over graphics, which brings me to....


*** GAMEPLAY ***

There are three gamemodes available: Story / Arcade / Duel
Let's begin with the story mode:

*story mode* consist out of a mission based (episodic) format.
Basically you'll move from objective to objective eliminating all who stand in your way in a linear path. At the end of the mission you'll usually face a boss (in this case a famous outlaw like Jesse James) and have a true mexican standoff. Eliminating enemies will grant you with experience points. These can be used to unlock and upgrade some abilities. You have three tiers of skill categories which favor the matching playstyle (dual wielding / rifleman / shotgunner)

Maybe the best part about the gameplay is the return of 'bullet-time' we know so well from Max Payne. Slow motion gameplay, dodging bullets, lining up headshots (or crotch shots if you're into that) and keep those combo's going.

Enemies are hiding behind objects, actively taking cover.
A.I. isn't too smart though, but hey it remains an arcade style shooter and not a tactical masterpiece.

You'll also have your basic hidden secrets (golden nuggets) which, if collected, tell a bit about the background story and also net you some extra experience points in the process.

Some minor QTE's on scripted occasions are also present.
Luckily they're quite scarce and not all that annoying.

For the die-hard cowboy a 'new game+' mode is included.
This keeps your hard-earned xp and existing skills intact for the next playthrough, if you so desire. The True West difficulty only unlocks after finishing the story mode once and offers an increased challenge due to the complete absence of a HUD.

*Arcade mode* is basically a rehash from the story mode missions. Run through a parcours to the finish line, eliminating bad guys and scoring as much combo's and points as possible. Nothing really special here, but it guarantees some additional gametime.

*Duel mode* offers a mexican standoff against 15 of the in-game outlaws. 'Billy: The Kid', Jesse James, The Daltons, Butch Cassidy etc. The principle consists out of keeping two pointers simultaneously in the correct zones. One pointer resembles your draw hand and hovers above your pistol. The longer you keep it in the correct zone the faster you will draw your weapon. The second pointer is aimed at your opponent and resembles accuracy. The longer you correctly aim at your opponent the more accurate your shot will be. Furthermore, you can kill your opponents 'honorably' (which means that you react upon them drawing first) or 'dishonorably' (which inevitably means that you draw first). Statistics about reaction time and even leaderboards are available.


*** CONCLUSION ***

Gunslinger is quite a solid arcade shooter. I didn't expect this after the debacle with 'The Cartel'. Everything blends really well together (graphics, gameplay, sound and the narrative storytelling). It's an immersive experience and The Wild West never looked this good. Sure, one may claim it is too short (ca. 8-12 hours) story mode, depending on skill, rushing or finding all collectibles etc.) It's linear and not free roam and maybe has little replay value, but in the end it doesn't really hurt the game. For a $15 listing, this is quite a steal. I know some $50 titles that are a lot worse.

If you're looking for a solid arcade shooter, you actually might be pleasantly suprised.
My rating an easy (8/10).
Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Pros:
- nice western theme
- decent gameplay
- nice challenge in arcade mode
- interesting story-telling, whose particularities are well exploited
- interesting duel gameplay : not exceptionally good, but a nice tentative to simulate the duels

Cons:
- lack of consistency due to the story : it's many little stories, so there's no real sense of attachment to the places & characters met (yes, this is both a pro & a con :-) )
- it's a train ride : you can't step away from the path, there's no exploration, and the enemies pop up in line to get killed, so skillwise it's pretty limited
- shotgun gameplay isn't satisfying : long range fights are better with the rifle, and medium & close range fights are better with the guns
- half-cooked musics meant to remind you all the popular musics from the most famous westerns, but without being actually them, so it feels very frustrating

reviewText:
This game brings out the true spirit of the wild west. There is a lot of fun to be had here, however it is important to know what kind of game this is.

What it is:
Linear, arcade style shooter, theatrical story line, repetitive

What it's not:
open world, multiplayer in any way, hard to learn

That said, I would like to list some of the pros and cons I noticed.

Pros:
-This game is POLISHED. I had a very smooth gaming experience from beginning to end
-Shooting mechanics are like butter
-story is fun and entertaining (unless your not into westerns, in which case i'm not sure why your even looking at this store page?)
-Difficulty ranging from cakewalk to WTF!?

Cons:
-very strictly single player
-dueling sucks unless you really stick with it
-linear gameplay can make it difficult if you get stuck on one part (you cant go back and get better, you just need to beat it)

Having said that I'm giving a thumbs up, this game is damn good at being what it is and is worth it even at full price

reviewText:
One word.

♥♥♥♥INGAWESOME.

Yes, that's one word.

Simply put, this game calls upon the spirit of the western.  The Good, The Bad, & The Ugly, Pale Rider, A Fistfull of Dollars, and even the genre bookend Unforgiven, are what this game emulates and channels perfectly.

I am simply shocked that I haven't played this game until now, and even feel a little guilty for not having paid full price for this on release day.

Despite the romanticism of the storytelling, I also enjoyed the Nuggets of Truth metagame (well not so much the finding secrets as the factual tidbits of history contained in each nugget) that added the historical flavour of the backdrop.

Even the multi-perspective story pacing was an enjoyable play element, which was always wonderfully used to guide the player along the on-rails story, making you rarely (if ever) disappointed with the linear nature of the game, but rather makes you appreciate that this is a story being told.

If you even have a passing appreciation for the western genre, you owe it to yourself to play this game.  And if you don't, what the ♥♥♥♥ is wrong with you?  Make yourself less broken by buying and playing this game.

reviewText:
Best shooter I've played in years. Simple, real fun like in oldschool Doom or Duke Nukem you just go and kill a lot. Sure enemies are dumb... but that IS THE POINT, 'cause you want to relax and kill them all :-) Sure, they hide but that's why you can kill with piercing shot or ricocheted bullet or you can use that time to reload weapon.

There is experience, levels and skills too... so you can kill more enemies, in less time, even easier.

You don't get lost in a game, don't have to solve puzzle or some riddles. But after long difficult day you don't want to stuck somewhere and think... you want just to kill them all, go ahead and kill more morons on the way...

However I have to complain about few things in the game: for example I've encountered some friendly NPCs that I was unable to kill. So be prepared for such disappointment. I also have serious problem to enjoy duels: you have to patiently aim for few seconds and wait... just wait... and then you maybe kill one guy. Seriously. During the game you mostly kill 5-10 guys in the time period you waste on dueling. It would also be more fun to carry all weapons, you have to choose between rifle and shotgun, while you dont want to do such stupid decisions! You want to have all the firepower.

Oh, and I miss the rocket jump. I did try TNT jump, althougt as for now only with very little success.

reviewText: I actually got this game because I just finished reading Preacher and felt like playing a Western. Oddly enough, the series itself was partly inspired by the Saint of Killers from Preacher. Needless to say, I was impressed with what I played. I wasn't too aware of the series in the first place, but after playing Gunslinger, I want to go back and play the other entries. You play as a man named Silas Greeves who walks into a bar and gains all the patrons' attention immediately. You then begin to tell them a story, and that's what you end up playing. As he tells his tale, you go through different typical Wild West environments, which change on the fly as Silas changes his story as he goes along, taking out whoever is in your way. Catching a bounty or getting revenge, everyone dies. And it never gets old, as you have a cool upgrade system that lets you earn experience points and use it on specific types of play styles. Ranged Rifle, Pistols, or Close Range Shotgun are available and mix up the gameplay very well. The story itself and voice acting was very good as well. Metal Gear Solid fans might notice Solidus Snake as Silas and Colonel Campbell as Ben.\n\nIf you have any interest in a unique shooter or a cool arcade like, over the top, action western game, I'd recommend it.

A straight no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t shooter at its core and still there went a surprisingly high amount of creative energy in the development of this highly recommended title!

reviewText:
At first glance fiction of the old west, particularly the game fiction, could strike you as rather stale. The dog eyed tropes of showdowns on Main Street at high noon and dynamite laced fire fights through the old mines seem to perpetually resurrect themselves like the uninspiring zombies of a genre long past its relevance. However like the zombie genre, there can always be room for reinvention.

The Call of Juarez franchise noticed this a while back when its western setting began to wear thin and has been in a constant cycle of reinvention ever since - Most notable being ‘The Cartel’s admirable but failed attempt to translate the genre into a gritty modern context.

In this sense Call of Juarez: Gunslinger is initially somewhat of an enigma. Without switching up its genre trappings in any obvious way, it still somehow manages to feel like a breadth of fresh air. Moreover, we see that rather than dancing around the clichés, Gunslinger has actually dug in and entrenched itself in the pulpy fiction of the old west. It gets away with this by cleverly framing its story arc around the rather dubious recounting of past glories by shady outlaw figure Silas Greaves – That is to say the game doesn’t tell his story – it tells the story of his story! This sleight of hand rather brilliantly comes to define the whole tone of the piece freeing up the plot and gunplay to really revel in a special brand of heightened reality.

Most immediately noticeable is the games beautifully measured visceral feedback. The guns are weighty, the shots are loud and the impacts produce a glorious crimson spray. This is a game that really wants you to enjoy the connection of a well aimed shot, going so far as to slow-mo the dispatched enemies bodies (300-style) as they flail gracefully into the ground.

Visceral reality extends into the environment as Silas recalls traversing a diverse array of locals, made unexpectedly exotic within the confines of this North-American genre. The recounted narrative then builds on this diversity by lending a unique brand of playfulness to the level design: Details of the story can be brought into question, and in response the narrator often bends or twists the nature of the playable reality without warning. As Silas haphazardly revises the flow of his story new paths can materialise, various characters can be swapped out and entire sections of the level design can be replayed along an altered narrative. This surreal manipulation married with the superb visual design creates a crisp, graphic and slightly oversaturated world that ends up feeling genuinely unique.

The rich landscape is not for idle rambling though as the campaign bolts from the starting line and then continues to ride at break-neck pace through the remainder its ripping yarn. Even the plot, quick-fired at you through in game narration and sideshow cutscenes serves more to set the roguish tone rather than attempt to construct any kind of complex narrative progression. In this and many other ways Gunslinger proves to be a master class on the good application of brevity. Slogging and grinding are most certainly off the menu for this insulin shot of action gunplay - Most should finish satisfied but with a healthy hunger for more!

And that’s the joy of Gunslinger - everything about its design has been streamlined to suck you into the zone of it pulpy hyper-realised action core. It’s a game that can genuinely brand itself as gun-running-fun and it has done this by releasing itself of many of the overreaching expectations other games in its category of man-shoot live or die by. Expectations perhaps generated by the traditional triple-A price point that Gunslinger has deliberately dived below.

While the fiction of the old West has long since developed into well trodden territory, its popularity can always be traced back to the youthful pleasures of heroic conflict by way of cowboys and Indians. Simple stuff really – morally unburdened heroes in a savage unpredictable frontier free to carve a path of righteous violence through an ensemble of joyfully hateful villains.  In returning to these roots Gunslinger has excelled in giving us an unapologetic slice of gunpowder-fuelled catharsis, once again making the old west feel new. YE-HA!

If you liked that piece check out my game review site:
Tonnochi Road [tonnochi.blogspot.co.uk]
Thanks for reading. Cheers Guys!

reviewText: A fantastic looking game, with shaded art reminiscent of games like Borderlands. The visuals, especially the characters and their introductions, are done very well, and this is complemented by the audio and the cut scenes. The depictions of dead enemies are also done masterfully, with both the ragdoll physics and the theatrical sprays of blood complementing the rest of the game, especially the beautiful background setting - whether it be an Wild West town, a train, a gold mine, swamps, or the mountains - the scenery can be breathtaking.\n\nThe gameplay mechanics themselves are also quite solid; and this game is very unique in how the Old West quick-draw stand-offs are depicted - tricky to master, but great fun. With several things you need to take note of; including focus and speed, and maybe even the ability to dodge, duels are a fun, if potentially frustrating addition to the game. This is complemented by the ability to slow down time and dodge bullets, in the style of Neo - it always brought a smile to my face when I dodged a bullet and heard an enemy say Did he just dodge a bullet?!" The skills also work quite well

reviewText:
This is one of those games that from the outside seam like nothing special, just another fps, but once you begin to play it turns out to be one of the most fun things ever.

Call of Juarez Gunslinger is a short 'All killer, no filler' arcade fps game. You are Silas Greaves - one of the fastest gunslingers in the wild west. A man who has spent most of his life in bullet-time.
This game has a unique way of telling it's story. Game starts in a saloon where Silas ends up telling his life story to a bunch of people. As he speaks you get to play through his life's events that he is narrating. Every now and again one of his listeners will interrupt Silas and tell his own version of the same story he has heard it somewhere. And that will effect the game word. The level will shift or time will rewind and the scene will play out in an entirely different manner.
Also thanks to this manner of story telling there is almost no downtime. You are always in action and the story is narrated while you are lining up headshots.

Visually this game is also neat. It may not be the most graphically advanced game around, but what it lacks in graphics it makes up with good art design. The colors are bright and sharp. Environments are beautifully designed and quite varied.
When it comes to visuals the only three sins this game commits are:
Lack of fov slider. The default fov is not terrible, but it's definitely not 90.
No anti-aliasing.
And there's a weird black border around the screen at all times.
Luckily all three of these issues can be fixed by the player. Fov and that border can be modified in a .ini file. And AA can be forced through you gpu's control panel.

And while the story mode is good and definitely worth a playthrough, where the game really shines is it's arcade mode. Arcade basically is an score attack/speedrun mode where you compete with your friends for the highest score. You get to play through more linear version of story modes levels where the objective is to kill everyone as fast as possible meanwhile maintaining a as high as possible combo.

All in all this is a short (~5h for the story mode and ~13h for a complete run) and super fun fps. If you are in a mood where you just want to shoot some people and feel super bad-♥♥♥ while doing it you can't go wrong with Call of Juarez Gunslinger.

reviewText:
I just finished playing through CoJ:Gunslinger so the experience is fresh in my mind for this review.

The whole storyline playthrough took me around 5 hours, and honestly it wasn't bad! The story itself isn't anything amazing, I dare say it may even be rather forgettable after a few days, but overall the fun wild west shootouts and satisfying/solid feel when hitting a target made it definately worthy of a recommendation. The game didn't manage to inspire any emotions relating to the story the protaganist is telling despite there being the availability for it (I don't want to give any spoilers so the details here will just stay this vague), but it wasn't boring or badly voice acted/written either. I think the developers put their time into the combat mechanics of the game as a priority and that side of the game was more than enough to pull the average storyline through to the end.

The gameplay was solid, well voice acted and the cutscenes were short and sweet, nothing too long that made me bored.

The variety of weapons basically boiled down to 3, a rifle, a pistol or a shotgun, and I felt like each of the weapons felt satisfying to use, though dual wield pistols felt abit clunky at times, I stuck with the single pistol if I had to use it, otherwise I used the rifle with a sawn off shotgun as a secondary weapon which worked nicely and proved to be fun.

I'm a veteran of fps games having played them for many many years, and yet the game still provided a challenge that I found highly enjoyable, and there's multiple difficulty settings to spice things up if you want another playthrough.

Replayability - It was good but now that I know the story it's not something I can realistic imagine playing through again. It was an enjoyable 1 time experience but there's nothing pulling me back in to try it again since it would just be more of the same, maybe just on the hardest difficulty mode.

Choices - There was only 1 choice that the player was asked to make and it was in regards to whether the main bad guy gets to live or die, I chose live and it was a peaceful end to the game. Don't expect to have any impact on any part of the 'world' like in other RPG's and it's not that kind of game, it's not a persistent world and quests/missions are given directly to you without needed to be collected. It's basically an old-school storyline shooter like the old Medal of Honor series.

All in all i'd say it'd be a shame if you missed out playing through this game, but i'd recommend grabbing it while it's on sale or on offer as a bundle (I got it from bundlestars) as based on the short amount of time it took to complete and the linear enviroments that leave the player with little to no decision making required, it's not really worth more than 5 euros in my opinion, but for that price it's a great game.

Overall rating - 6.5/10: It didn't wow me and the story was forgettable, but the combat was fun and the enviroments were pretty.

reviewText: Gunslinger doesn't have any relation to the first two games in the series (this also works as a plus side, since it also doesn't have any relation to The Cartel), but it's still a really good Western story with a unique narrative format. The campaign can be finished in around 4-6 hours depending on whether or not you look around for collectibles (It also has New Game+, and an unlockable difficulty that disables the HUD and crosshairs, so there's enough reason to go back through again), so if length is a factor you might want to wait for a discount, but it's absolutely worth buying if you're into Westerns.

reviewText:
Call of Juarez Gunslinger is kind of like a rollercoaster ride - it's short, on rails, but incredibly fun.

Pros:
+The way Silas tells the story and the game plays around with the narrative is really cool
+Guns feel great to use
+Soundtrack is pretty good
+Scenery is varied, with some awesome stages
+No puzzles, no stealth sections, no waiting around for NPCs to finish giving exposition, it's about 100% shooting people

Cons:
-The AI can feel cheap at times, having perfect accuracy even from behind cover
-Sometimes it's hard to tell just how much health you have left, so you'll have to take cover and wait for your health to regenerate. It's not a huge problem but it can be irritating at times.
-Some annoying invisible walls

Personal gripes:
-Duels are a bit awkward and take some getting used to
-Kind of sucks that you can carry only 2 weapons at once
-The campaign is pretty short, which is a shame because I can't get enough of Silas Greaves.

If you want a short but really fun FPS that is 100% about shooting people, there's no reason not to get this, especially considering it's low price.

reviewText:
I shouldn't start a recommendation with a comparison, but I know no other way to talk about this game.

Straight to the point:
Red Dead Redemption is the best Western game ever, and it's among the five best games of all times.
Having said this, and having played Gunslinger shortly after Red Dead Redemption, I can only say good things about this Call of Juarez.

The narrative techniques are unique, very original. You listen the oral narration of an old man, and through that voice you become witness of all the Western legends.
As you advance in the game, it only gets better, MUCH better.
But I can't say anymore because it is up to you to discover what I'm hiding.

Being Gunslinger an extremely fun FPS and Red Dead Redemption a sandbox, both games are incomparable, but somehow I do think Call of Juarez: Gunslinger has something very special.

In other words: if you don't have a PS3, buy one just for Red Dead Redemption.

If you have a PC, just purchase Call of Juarez: Gunslinger.

And BANG BANG!

9/10  Worth every penny.

Gunslinger is easily the best of the Call of Juarez games. I liked Bound in Blood, but Gunslinger has none of the weak parts it did. Thanks to Gunslinger being a budget title, they keep it simple. This game is freaking awesome. It combines FPS(First person shooting)
with arcade elements such as getting points for kills, getting better
scores for making headshots, and killing people in certain ways
(much like Bulletstorm). It rewards you for making certain kills with
points that you can use to level up your character and give him certain
skills.

There are three difficulties in this game. This includes Normal, Hard, and
True West modes. Normal is pretty easy, with a small challenge here and there,
Hard is super tough and you have to take cover more often to live, and finally True West
Mode. It's like Hard, but the game takes away your Heads-up-Display. So things like your
ammo count and even your aiming reticle. So basically it's hard difficulty with no HUD.
Hard was very tough near the ending, so if you want a challenge you should play this
game on Hard difficulty the first time you play it.

This game also goes back to its Wild West roots (Which is where it should be)
and it helps this game a lot. It has an interesting story that keeps you playing
from start to finish. If you have the money, I suggest that you give this game a shot!

reviewText:
I grew up on Clint Eastwood and Terrence Hill Westerns. So as a kid, I wanted to be Nobody or Blondie or Jose Wales...
In this game, that's exactly who I got to be: a real wild west gun man!

It's not a very long game. I finished the storyline in normal mode in a little over 9h.
And I started right over in the highest difficulty!!!

And here's why:
- The story is Good. It's got a good dose of humour although I don't think it should have been tagged it as 'comedy'.
- The mechanic of the story telling is fun and original.
- The duel mechanic is simply brilliant. It's simple, yet, not easy. And you really feel like you've won the duel when you finally do.
- The skilling system works really well and is balanced. You can pick your play style and skill up accordingly.
- Great graphics.
- Awesome soundtrack.
- 2 additional game modes. Arcade (score points over set levels) and Duel (self explanatory :)
- Lever action riffle!!!

What can I say? I love this game!
Definitely Recommended!

reviewText:
If you like FPS and Cowboys, then you have absolutely NO reason NOT to buy this game!

The story mode has one of the most unique story-telling in FPS history! Think of it as Bastion's story telling, but are more hilarious and badass!

The gun plays are solid and powerful, you can feel the power and the satisfaction after killing each baddies.

The game also has a level-up system. Each time you leveled up, you gain a skill point in which you can use to purchase a skill from the skill tree which either specializes in duel wielding pistols, rifles or shotguns.

The gameplays are split into 2 parts, the normal FPS which is fast-paced and badass, and the Duel part which tests your reflex.

I don't know what else to say, everything in this game is AWESOME! The gameplay, the story, the music, the sound effects, they are all superb, on the dot and satisfying!

No multiplayer tho, no problem. Also no open world, no problem!

The game have 3 game modes, Story, Arcade and Duel. Story is the campaign. Arcade is where you trying to rack your high score by chaining combo kills and Duel is well, duels!

Don't worry, this game is far, FAR better than Call of Juarez The Cartel (let's not mention that game ever again). For it's $15 price tag, I would say that it's worth every cent of my money, heck I think that they deserve more!

For you FPS enthusiasts, you would most probably love this game!

[HIGHLY RECOMMENDED]

A great little game. Took 3 hours to beat on normal, and theres still a new game+, duel mode, and arcade mode. The shooting is fluid, with plenty of action. The narration is witty as well, with the scenery changing as the narrator remembers part of the story. There is also 3 different skill paths to take, either shotgun, rifle, or duel pistols. All in all, a great game.

Call of Juarez Gunslinger is an intresting title to say the least. It is a first person shooter takes inspiration from the arcade shooters of old, but with a beautiful aesthetic, some progression systems, and a surprisngly indepth story and intresting way to deliver it.

The combat in this game feels very solid. Everything from the range of weapons to sound design ensure that every bullet you fire feels different and has an impact on the enemies.

Furthermore, the aesthetic fits the game well. It's stylized look douses everything in bright colors, and everything seems to pop out a little more because of it.

The story is surprsingly intresting, and is told as a sequence of memories. This means that during the middle of a gunfight the narrator may remember something new, drastically changing the playing field.

Considering that this is a very cheap game for what it is, I'd give this game a look if you were intrested in a good old fashioned shoot em up.

Funny, challenging and good gameplay, interesting storyline told by the main character/narrator. The game takes place in an immesive Western setting, with famous villains such as Jesse James, Billy the Kid and many others.\nYou may even find answers to some important questions
date: such as: just who was Silas Greaves? And just what gun is best for shooting guys in the face?"\n8.5/10"

reviewText: A cheap, but very funny game in my opinion. Even more worth the money if you like the Wild West stories.

Gunslinger is a  complete surprise and Techland (of Dead Island) bring a great looking stylized game with compelling mechanics and an unexpectedly fun (even if predictable half way through) story. It's a cowboy shooter that has bullet time, leveling up, skills, and a story that is conveyed by a narration method reminiscent of Super Giant Games' Bastion.

While there is an arcade mode and challenges, the campaign is so fun and engaging that after the approximately six hours you put in to complete it, you'll wish there was more.

Frankly, I'd pay another $15 if they put out a sequal that is just as substantial. I'd even be interested in seeing them tell other stories in other settings (modern day, 1950s, future) using this same structure.

This was a complete blast and from a developer and franchise I didn't expect it from. It's a reasonable buy at $15 and if you find it on sale at some point, it would be a shame to miss it at all.

Very Surprisingly Outstanding Comeback for the Call Of Juarez series, they went downhill with the Cartel modern day and age sequel. However, this seems much back into their roots with a new innovation and I'd highly recommend it, much worth the fairly cheap price for the game. Enjoy.

It's a fun game that doesn't use Uplay.

Great game from the amount of played. Enjoyed the leveling system and how you can really suit it to how your prefer to play. reviewText:
I grew up on Clint Eastwood and Terrence Hill Westerns. So as a kid, I wanted to be Nobody or Blondie or Jose Wales...
In this game, that's exactly who I got to be: a real wild west gun man!

It's not a very long game. I finished the storyline in normal mode in a little over 9h.
And I started right over in the highest difficulty!!!

And here's why:
- The story is Good. It's got a good dose of humour although I don't think it should have been tagged it as 'comedy'.
- The mechanic of the story telling is fun and original.
- The duel mechanic is simply brilliant. It's simple, yet, not easy. And you really feel like you've won the duel when you finally do.
- The skilling system works really well and is balanced. You can pick your play style and skill up accordingly.
- Great graphics.
- Awesome soundtrack.
- 2 additional game modes. Arcade (score points over set levels) and Duel (self explanatory :)
- Lever action riffle!!!

What can I say? I love this game!
Definitely Recommended!
it has such deep wild west feeling. one of the best western games I have ever played

V.good gameplay
Amazing storyline
arcade mode give u alot of fun and challenges
i like

lets keep it short and sweet, bought this game on sale for 8 or 9$ i beleive. beat it the same day in about 5 hours of gameplay. so lets do a short pro/con list to sum this game up. pros=amazing story, nice voicing, nice twist, amazing ais, awesome overall gameplay. cons= short story. so overall this game was extremely well made and nicely done, so good i just bought every other call of juarez game on the market. a def have, buy it you wont regret it.

Bought this yesterday along with FC3 Blood Dragon. However, i am pleased to say that this game is such as refreshing face to the FPS genre, and the best part is that this game despite being published by Ubisoft DOESN'T REQUIRE UPLAY!

You play as a man called Silas Greaves, who tells you and a few others at the bar about his past adventures. It's all narrated throughout the course of the gameplay! I absolutely like that about this game as well. During the gameplay sometimes he changes things up a little bit which either rewind you back to a certain point in the level where he recalls that it played out differently or just half-a**ed a secret pathway or entrance somewhere nearby that really wasn't there before.

Either way the gunplay is amazing! The guns feel as though they really have that kick" to them as you blast bullets into the skulls of you're enemies. You also gain bonus/skill points for killing in unique ways (kind of like Bulletstorm
date: but not that hyper-extreme). Everything else such as the leveling system
recommended: the perk system and upgrade system are very rewarding and will most definitely help you and make you a force to be rekoned with!\n\nI haven't played this game for longer than 2 hours and yet it's already getting my review. I cannot reccommend this game enough! Try the demo and see if you like it before buying it. Or you can just straight up buy this damn awesome game right now and not read on any further!"

Gunslinger is a total surprise. This game has more style and execution than you'd ever expect from a $15 Techland title. It's difficult for me to imagine what type of person this game wouldn't appeal to.

The gameplay is tight and fast moving, the art is extremely stylised, the writing is intentionally silly, but also very well done. The mechanic of playing along as someone tells the tales of his life, embellishments and all, along with revisions opens the way for this game to do some really intriguing set pieces. There are kernels of ideas in this game you'd never expect from a small title.

If you like westerns, pretty much every famous outlaw and cowboy are present at some point in this game. It's the Assassin's Creed of late 1800s America in that way. Silas is somehow involved in the entirety of the wild west. I loved this game. You should give it a shot.

A bit bias as a big fan of the Western Era, but Gunslinger is a ton of fun.  It takes liberties with history, of course, but it's still a great western story.    The skill system is a great way to get a little more out of the play as various kill types yield different XP amounts, rewarding head shots and range the most.  You can then specialize toward your preferred style and go from there.\n\nThere are three main modes.  The Story itself, which is pretty interesting if you can set aside reality for a bit.   A little suspension of disbelief is needed for any game, though.   The next mode is Arcade, where you play through aiming for points and trying to hit high scores.  And the final is duels, where you run a gauntlet of quick draw duels.   Each mode is fun and worth a play through.
Awesome game!\nGreat story and gameplay. Enchanting graphics.
One of the best single-player FPS games of the year.  Highly overlooked, but well worth the admission price.
Gunslinging fun, this title is worth more than $15. The story telling is great and the nuggets of information you collect are very educational.

Get this while it's on sale. It has absolutely nothing to do with the previous CoJ games, but the gunplay is very satisfying and the story telling is pretty great. Aside from that I don't have much to say. It is single player only, but has challenges and leaderboards of you are into that stuff. The cellshaded/comic book artstyle is nice to look at and works well with the way the story is told. If you are looking for something to pass the time and get your cowboy fix in, then pick this up while it's cheap(er).\n\nI do not accept responsibility if you are not satisfied with your purchase.
Fast-paced gameplay with great Western shootouts and an amusing story that isn't afraid of breaking the fourth wall. Overall a very solid, enjoyable game!

Awsome, just down right fun!  I love all the sarcastic comments made by the AI while you are flushing them out. Weapon upgrades along the way, keep what you got or take theirs upon their demise. This has been a nice change from other 1st person shooters, lively and realistic, shadows, flapping curtens in your line of sight, enemy hiding and taunting you as you clear out the Wild West of several old time hombres from the history books. And if you aren't feeling enough satisfaction running and gunning them down, you can always go into gunfighter mode and have a showdown in the middle of the street, real gunfighter style. I highly recommend this game / experience because it is very well done in the programming and graphics. A must have 1st person shhooter in my opinion!
dis ich asum

I have difficulty actually beating fairly standard games like this one, but because of the very well done theme of the game, and a nice story telling style they got me playing long enough to at least finish the game.

Don't get me wrong, I don't dislike the game's mechanics, they are actually very satisfying and I had the same kind of blast playing this, that I have when I play games like Killing Floor, with really a nice weapon-feel, I just have a problem completing First Person Shooters (FPS) and the like.

The story is told partly with graphic novel style cutscenes and with voice over by some of the characters. It uses a frame story of a few men (and a lady) in a saloon, telling a story of one of the men's life in highlights.

If you're a big fan of the FPS genre and even like scores in games this should be on your to-buy list. (If you have on of those.)
It is pretty short, though.

Fast paced, stylish and satisfying first person shooter. Like a movie of Quentin Tarantino's as a game.

The game begins as the main character enters a saloon and sits down with a few people to tell them a story about his adventures, as the game itself is the story being told. The main character keeps narrating the story throughout the game, and the people sitting with him talk as well, so in a way you are following two stories at the same time. What makes it really interesting, is that the interraction between the story-teller and the listeners sometimes affect your surroundings and the events in the game, keeping it interesting and full of surprises. So story-wise, the game is excellent.

The visual style of the game is very stylish, comic-like and gritty. There's a lot of blood, just like you'd expect. The music, the sound effects and the voice acting are all excellent and complement that certain wild west feel.

The controls are smooth and responsive, and shooting enemies is satisfying. There are three weapon classes for you to select depending on your preferred playstyle. The game has some well implemented quicktime events.

I completed the game on Hard difficulty setting, and I think it was sometimes hard to follow the narrative in a tight spot as you try to survive, but I don't think it should be passed as a critique. There were also a couple of moments that, in my opinion, required more trial and error than good reflexes and timing. I encountered a few minor bugs in the game, but nothing that would affect the gameplay experience. The game is a bit short, but one hell of a ride.

If you get it for about 10 euros (or dollars) or even less, it's definitely worth it.

As a bonus note: It's almost like playing a modern version of Sunset Riders.

reviewText:
Great western theme FPS with a short but fantastic story and great gunplay.

Worth it.

I Love western games.  Was heart breaking that Red Dead Redemption never made it to PC's.  Call Of Juarez is better in some ways.  The history lessons, that weave into the games top notch story line, are spot on.  The graphics are fantastic.  The hit boxes are great. EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME IS ON THE BALL!  Did i mention the voice overs? GREAT!!! GET IT!!
Thanks to steam community for recomending this game so much. Funnest FPS you'll play at this price point. I'd say it's to cheap for what this game delivers.

Call of Juarez Gunslinger is an intresting title to say the least. It is a first person shooter takes inspiration from the arcade shooters of old, but with a beautiful aesthetic, some progression systems, and a surprisngly indepth story and intresting way to deliver it.

The combat in this game feels very solid. Everything from the range of weapons to sound design ensure that every bullet you fire feels different and has an impact on the enemies.

Furthermore, the aesthetic fits the game well. It's stylized look douses everything in bright colors, and everything seems to pop out a little more because of it.

The story is surprsingly intresting, and is told as a sequence of memories. This means that during the middle of a gunfight the narrator may remember something new, drastically changing the playing field.

Considering that this is a very cheap game for what it is, I'd give this game a look if you were intrested in a good old fashioned shoot em up.

Funny, challenging and good gameplay, interesting storyline told by the main character/narrator. The game takes place in an immesive Western setting, with famous villains such as Jesse James, Billy the Kid and many others.\nYou may even find answers to some important questions
date: such as: just who was Silas Greaves? And just what gun is best for shooting guys in the face?"\n8.5/10"

I have difficulty actually beating fairly standard games like this one, but because of the very well done theme of the game, and a nice story telling style they got me playing long enough to at least finish the game.

Don't get me wrong, I don't dislike the game's mechanics, they are actually very satisfying and I had the same kind of blast playing this, that I have when I play games like Killing Floor, with really a nice weapon-feel, I just have a problem completing First Person Shooters (FPS) and the like.

The story is told partly with graphic novel style cutscenes and with voice over by some of the characters. It uses a frame story of a few men (and a lady) in a saloon, telling a story of one of the men's life in highlights.

If you're a big fan of the FPS genre and even like scores in games this should be on your to-buy list. (If you have on of those.)
It is pretty short, though.

A simple fast-paced shooter with an awesome atmosphere. It's very solid (nothing too innovative and crazy), and you can easily pick it up and put it down again (not as in getting bored).
You'll feel like a badass, but still be vulnerable enough to play strategically and actually feel a little like your life is on the line (atleast on hard). It has a minimalistic skill tree, which makes it easy to go through the game again with a different path.
The music is GREAT if you prefer that the pieces are interesting enough to stand for their own.
The art-style seems to me like a colorful sharper version of Borderlands', which makes it quite fantastic.

This is an excellent game at an excellent price. ($15 is what I bought it for)
It's got all the bells and whistles you would expect to find in a $60 dollar blockbuster. It's very well made, very few/no bugs, an excellent story and the gameplay is, well, everything. Gameplay is what games are all about, and this game makes you never want to quit playing it. It is just so fun. I don't really know what else to say.

The story is interesting, the gameplay is unbelievably addicting, the art style is pleasing, and the sounds are fun to listen to as well.

I highly recommend this game, and I think it's one of the few single player ego shooters that have really managed to stand out of it's category in the last few years.

The story is set in the year 1910 in the late years of the wild west, where the sixty years old bounty hunter Suarez meets a few of his fans in a bar and tells them about his greatest adventures. You play through these adventures while Suarez narrates in the background, often while having arguements with the people around him. The funny thing is that that the memory of Suarez isn't as good as it used to be, so the mistakes he makes while telling the story affect the gameplay while you are in it.

For instance, one time he was fighting a gang of criminals called the cowboys"

reviewText: Don't underestimate this game: its foon

Some console-leaning design decisions and a few frustrating sections where the checkpoint system paired with quick-timed events can breed frustration, but on the whole a solid, stylish FPS with light RPG unlocks and oodles of replayability if you like the cut of its jib. Short, sweet, and to-the-point, but oozing with a modern spaghetti-western aesthetic with a satisfying representation of period guns. Worth a full $15? Maybe. Worth it for a discount during a Steam Sale? Without question, especially if you're looking for a modern FPS that doesn't have you decked out like a US Special Forces operative.

Haven't had this much fun with a single player shooter for quite a while.

Really enjoyed the setting and environment, eventhough I've never been a huge fan of cowboys and the wild west as a kid. The levels for the most part are very vibrant and colorful. Gunplay feels great as well. It's hard to explain but the combination of the looks of the guns, the sound effects, the powers you can unlock and just overall weapon handling make this game so much fun to play though. The game also has a really fun story with pretty cool story telling techniques which I won't spoil here.

One thing that you should keep in mind is that it's pretty short. I played through it on Hard mode in about 4.5 hours. While there are some collectibles and new modes to unlock after you're done, it would have been neat if the base game offered more levels. However since the game is already pretty cheap and goes on sale rather often, it's not a huge deal.

If you're looking for a fun singleplayer shooter (of which there haven't been a lot recently if you ask me) then give this game a shot. If you're the type of guy that likes to get everything done in a game (as in getting all achievements and collectibles ect.) then there's no harm in getting it at full price. Otherwise I'd say wait until it goes on sale.

reviewText:
If you ever wanted to feel like a cowboy, play this game. The story is based upon the baddies of the Wild West and you're going to take everybody down in order to avenge your brother, so obviously you're going to be the biggest badass of all time.

Now there aren't a ton of guns to play around with considering the time period, but this might have just contributed to the slick gunplay. The guns fire in tremendous fashion and reloading can be quick and fluid and not break the action.

Put this gunplay with the satisfying arcade-style system of scoring, pair that with skills that you can unlock and a meter that allows you to slow down time, and you have an incredible experience.

There are some games where I only really like the feel of one of the guns. This game, I like the feel of all the guns.

It's called Gunslinger for a reason, folks.
It has cowboys.

While the sampling size of Western themed FPS games is pretty much nil and as a person who has played the first two Call of Juarez games, I think it goes without saying that Call of Juarez: Gunslinger is the best Western themed FPS I've ever played. You play an old bounty hunter telling his tales of his past the western frontier to the patrons in a saloon and I won't go any further as the game is filled with many twists, turns and surprises throughout. The good is that the story is very good with excellent voice acting, nice gunplay and beautiful cel shaded graphics. While some of the environments do repeat themselves  (mostly due to how the narrator is telling the story) you'll still do battle in valleys, forests, gold mines, swamps and of course a train. One of the unique points of this game is the duelling and it definitely takes some practice but you'll get better as you go which adds satisfaction to when you win. It took me about eight hours to compete but I was scouring the levels for the unlockables, which give you some real life history of some of the characters you come across. If you enjoy the old west, this is definitely the game for you. The MSRP is $14.99 which is quite fair but if you can get it for 66%-75% off well that's just a (train) robbery. 9/10 from me.

I've played one of the other CoJ games and hated them, as I'm not much of an FPS player, and those games are somewhat lacking even as FPS.  But Gunslinger tweaks the genre just enough with a small mechanic that could have become an annoying gimmick if used irresponsibly.  Driver: San Francisco did the same thing for me with driving games (which I also usually hate) by integrating its weird mind shift mechanic into the gameplay and story.  In this case, Gunslinger rolls with an incredibly unreliable narrator, which isn't too unfamiliar on its own... but the game goes even further by changing the world to fit the narration.  In some ways, Gunslinger reminded me of Bastion (another of my favorite small games), but in Bastion the narrator reacts to the changing world, while in Gunslinger, the world reacts to the changing narration.  I guess it doesn't hurt that I'm a huge fan of spaghetti Western drama, but I found the actual shooting mechanics and skill trees quite good in their own right.

Don't let the Call of Juarez name fool you: This is a very strong arcade-shooter with a unique style. Unlike other games in the series, the mechanics here are spot-on and satisfying -- and improved with layering on a solid scoring and combo system, and a rewarding, divergent upgrade path. Even better, though, is how the game tells its tale as a series of remembered half-truths. Hyperbole, corrections, misdirections, and other storytelling tricks are weaved through the gameplay in a way that, while not maybe groundbreaking, certainly keeps the action from getting overly predictable or repetitive. Best of all, a western game finally gets duels right!

reviewText:
What Call of Juarez Gunslinger inspires in me is the competitiveness of the old school arcade shooters. Gunslinger offers three modes; story mode and arcade mode and duel mode. Duel mode is mostly forgettable with a minigame style showdown.

It is the arcade mode and story mode that is the standout of the game. For me, Arcade mode alone makes this game worth it. The game is semi-fast paced point-based first person shooter. In arcade mode, shooting enemies yields points. Shooting enemies in the head, yields more points. Shooting enemies in succession yields multipliers, which yields even more points. Points galore! Yes, the arcade mode is about getting the highest score possible and this really makes the game competitive especially for those perfectionists and competitive gamers.

The story mode is an added benefit. The story itself is surprisingly good, offering a unique storytelling style. Without spoiling it, it will definitely keep you entertained and even a few chuckles along the way.

If I had a minor complaint, it would be that the arcade mode stages are all based on the stages from the Story mode. It would've been nice to have a larger variety of stages not already seen from the story mode. But this is a minor complaint, and doesn't detract from the fact that this game is such a solid shooter.

The game's gimmick is also a bullet time style power that slows everyone down. Nothing innovative in this aspect, but the gunplay makes this game highly satisfying to play. For the low price point, you will certainly get your money's worth for it.

Call of juarez Gunslinger is the perfect fix for bloodlust! Sure the story is a bit dry and you actually play the same level every time you come to a town, witch i found quite anoying, but the feeling of fully reloading two rangers and then just running down an ally or a mineshaft while shooting everything you see, and there is just blood everywhere and you keep shooting and when youre almost dead you manage loading one bullet in the chamber and you hit the remainig bad guy right between the eyes and watch the red fluit pooring out of the mans head. Man. That is satisfying!

This is most definitely a shooter on rails.  But unlike many of the other modern FPSes that place the player on rails, this one is done right.  Call of Juarrez: Gunslinger bleeds style.  It sets out to guide the player through an entertaining FPS experience rife with cinematic set pieces, plenty of humor, and a metric buttload of style.  It pulls it off in spades.  I honestly have not had so much fun in a rails-style shooter in over a decade!

At first I had no intention to play this mainly due to the fact that it is set in the west, which is something I am not really fond of. But I have changed my mind after playing it. Other than it is a fun FPS game, what mainly matters is the humour. Love the narration throughout the game. It is not just run around and shoot things but LISTEN and shoot things.

Another point is the scenery. The game is beautiful in that aspect.

The game modes are interesting too. You have the choice to either pick up the story and play or just spare 10-15 minutes and play some quick mini game.

I recommend this game but the only problem is that I felt it was a little short. But again, it is more than enough for the price.

The good:
- Graphics are very detailed
- Story Mode has an engaging story
- Gameplay is challenging and entertaining
- Arcade Mode is exciting

The bad:
- No multiplayer
- Difficult to navigate in some levels because of unlite areas

Call of Juarez: Gunslinger: An old west story with an arcade style feeling and, sweet gun-play mechanics makes for a refreshing change from the typical military first-person shooters which dominate the industry. Gunslinger not only offers great visuals, voice acting, music and an interesting story, it does it all while being priced at $15.00USD. The game is fairly simple and straightforward but, adds enough in to make it interesting such as a slow-mo mode, three separate skill trees and a great duel system. While the story is rather short, lasting only about 4-5 hours, it has enough extras and content here to make the story alone worth the asking price and, at the end of the day the only reason not too is if you’re really not into first-person shooters or you’re that sick of them.

-Double Thumbs Up from Royial

I have difficulty actually beating fairly standard games like this one, but because of the very well done theme of the game, and a nice story telling style they got me playing long enough to at least finish the game.

Don't get me wrong, I don't dislike the game's mechanics, they are actually very satisfying and I had the same kind of blast playing this, that I have when I play games like Killing Floor, with really a nice weapon-feel, I just have a problem completing First Person Shooters (FPS) and the like.

The story is told partly with graphic novel style cutscenes and with voice over by some of the characters. It uses a frame story of a few men (and a lady) in a saloon, telling a story of one of the men's life in highlights.

If you're a big fan of the FPS genre and even like scores in games this should be on your to-buy list. (If you have on of those.)
It is pretty short, though.

As someone who generally dislikes first-person shooters, I quite enjoyed Gunslinger. The voice acting and narrative techniques used are pretty good for a video game, the gameplay is fairly simple and easy to get into, and the art and sound direction are quite strong. It actually features a really interesting use of the unreliable narrator, which I haven't seen before to this extent in video games. The gameplay itself is twitch-based, but there are a lot of character abilities you can use to supplement your skills if you find you're having a hard time dealing with the enemies (generally by slowing down time, or providing a kind of auto-target).

As for what my complaints would be... I don't really have any. It's exactly what I expected it to be: a fun, good-looking shooter with a short, simple, well-told story. I didn't encounter any bugs, crashes, bad level design, or anything of the sort. While it does depict a world of macho mostly-white men, there's no blatant racism or sexism of the kind you'd find in other games if the genre (including, apparently, the other Call of Juarez games), and the narrator has moments of simple empathy with people from other cultures or other walks of life in a way that feels humanizing.

Gunslinger is an enjoyable, fun way to whittle away a few hours (it really doesn't take long to finish the game, which is great for people with lives). It's not amazing by any means, but not every game has to be. As a bonus, it's one of the few Ubisoft games I've purchased that doesn't force Uplay on you.

Coming from the Call of Juarez Bound in Blood I wasnt expecting to much from this, however I must say im very impressed. The story mode is broken into levels with a neat animated story, makes for an interesting change. Fun level designs that are linear with secrets sprinkled all over, I think the replay value is good! I recommend!

reviewText:
This game is linear and short, but sometimes that is exactly what works to tell a story, have fun, and not let things become monotonous. The price, for about 8 hours to complete the main story, and still have the arcade mode and a couple of bits and bobs, seems fair.

Call of Juarez Gunslinger captures the wild west fictional setting better than any other game I've ever played, with amazing graphics, great voice acting, and excellent use of story-telling devices, playing with time, tempo, and look & feel, so well that the cinematographers ought to be commended.

If you don't like the western theme, then you might want to give this a miss, otherwise totally worth it on one of them Steam offers.

Call of Juarez Gunslinger is an intresting title to say the least. It is a first person shooter takes inspiration from the arcade shooters of old, but with a beautiful aesthetic, some progression systems, and a surprisngly indepth story and intresting way to deliver it.

The combat in this game feels very solid. Everything from the range of weapons to sound design ensure that every bullet you fire feels different and has an impact on the enemies.

Furthermore, the aesthetic fits the game well. It's stylized look douses everything in bright colors, and everything seems to pop out a little more because of it.

The story is surprsingly intresting, and is told as a sequence of memories. This means that during the middle of a gunfight the narrator may remember something new, drastically changing the playing field.

Considering that this is a very cheap game for what it is, I'd give this game a look if you were intrested in a good old fashioned shoot em up.

Lots of fun, it really feels like you're in a gritty western. Seems incredibly cheap considering how short a time the game's been out as of writing this review, and the quality of the game.

After the first playthrough you can start again on the hardest difficulty and/or with Story Mode+ to keep your skills etc., and although the game is very story driven (more on that), the action is enjoyable and replay value is high all things considered. It also has Arcade and Duel modes where you can compete with your friends scores on leaderboards.

The story is being told by your venerable self, Silas Greaves, many years after the fact in a saloon, and the narrative constantly follows you through the game, adding well timed humour. As has been mentioned by others, the game doesn't take itself too seriously.

Fantastic scenery, I often found myself looking off over the vistas at just how realistically it's been recreated - very beautiful. They've tried to make as good a game as is reasonably possible, and I think they've done a great job. Personally I would have liked it to be a little more open world.. perhaps a choice in taking bounties etc, but that's not really in the scope of the game. It's a linear story for the main game, just so you know :)

reviewText: Gunslinger is a mesh of Tarantino's over-the-top gore and action, with arcadey twitch FPS relying on bullet time, with story telling somewhat similar to Bastion. It's pretty great. You are getting a prettty predictable story here with a weak twist, but the gameplay and ranking system is fun enough to grab you for a couple play-throughs. I will say this though: Dueling sucks. I hated it so much. But I think the rest of the game is enough to warrant a purchase if you catch this one on sale.

A very good western shooter, COJ:G definitely compares favorably with Red Dead Redemption and Outlaws. The story revolves around the concept of the unreliable narrator, and does it well.\n\nIts short length (~5 hours) works very well with its design - the game has a nice, streamlined flow with very little bloat. There are some clever story twists, too. Play on Hard for just enough challenge to make things interesting.

The story in this game is //so// good, although the gameplay mechanics themselves may not be perfect, the story is enough to pull you through all the parts where the slightly sloppy controls send you into an uncontrollable rage.\n\nbuy this now pl0x

Gunslinger is a total surprise. This game has more style and execution than you'd ever expect from a $15 Techland title. It's difficult for me to imagine what type of person this game wouldn't appeal to.

The gameplay is tight and fast moving, the art is extremely stylised, the writing is intentionally silly, but also very well done. The mechanic of playing along as someone tells the tales of his life, embellishments and all, along with revisions opens the way for this game to do some really intriguing set pieces. There are kernels of ideas in this game you'd never expect from a small title.

If you like westerns, pretty much every famous outlaw and cowboy are present at some point in this game. It's the Assassin's Creed of late 1800s America in that way. Silas is somehow involved in the entirety of the wild west. I loved this game. You should give it a shot.

A bit bias as a big fan of the Western Era, but Gunslinger is a ton of fun.  It takes liberties with history, of course, but it's still a great western story.    The skill system is a great way to get a little more out of the play as various kill types yield different XP amounts, rewarding head shots and range the most.  You can then specialize toward your preferred style and go from there.\n\nThere are three main modes.  The Story itself, which is pretty interesting if you can set aside reality for a bit.   A little suspension of disbelief is needed for any game, though.   The next mode is Arcade, where you play through aiming for points and trying to hit high scores.  And the final is duels, where you run a gauntlet of quick draw duels.   Each mode is fun and worth a play through.

I have finished that game and it is definitely one of the best shooter in its style. The story is well narrated and our hero will meet most of the Wild West famous bandits like Jesse James or the Daltons. Graphics are pretty good and recreate a charming atmosphere. The sounds are excellent and gives you the feeling to have powerful guns in your hands. On the bad side, no multiplayer, the level design is quite linear (not open world) and repetitive, the enemies can act stupidly sometimes and the game is quite short, about 6-8 hours to complete it. However once you have complete the game, it will unlock several game modes, like the Authentic difficulty where you don't have any UI or ammo count on the screen :)\nIf you are looking for a good Wild West shooter, you won't regret buying this game during Sales or Daily offer.
great western FPS, totally recommended!

played it some time ago and loved it, great combat and diverse weapon selection, really good story with a strong presentation that makes you keep playing as you hear sillas narrate his adventure, visuals are really nice and have some great environments that capture the time period really well\n\n8.5/10

If you like CoD style shooters and/or westerns give this a shot. It's really pretty great and  goes in some surprising directions. The mechanics are solid and fun and the framing device of the story makes the ridiculous nature of your modern shooter narrative work surprisingly well.\n\nA couple tips to maximize enjoyability: play it with a 360 controller if you got one and turn on the objective marker in the options.
nice game !!!!!!!        :)

Outlaws + Bastion and/or The Stanley Parable = Call of Juarez: Gunslinger. I played the other Juarez games, and they were nothing special. But this...THIS game stands out. I bought it ages ago in a sale, and only recently got around to downloading it to try out. I anticipated deleting it fairly quickly, but then it surprised me. The unreliable narrator constantly telling and revising his story as you play was straight out of Bastion or The Stanley Parable, although with less (but not entirely infrequent) humor than the latter. Add in a bit of the spaghetti western flavor of the LucasArts classic Outlaws, and you have a recipe for one of the most enjoyable shooters I've played in years.\n\nHIGHLY recommend.

I recommend this game all fans of western like mee. :) I hope in next CoJ game

Only annoying things I found so far is the special weapons you unlock via skills still have to be looted from dead enemies and sometimes AI opponents get stuck in weird places (lumberyard wood-piles).

The arcade mode consists of well crafted timed runs that require you to play trough a map in one run and shoot an enemy every four seconds to keep the score timer running. Let's just say that if you're not into the open world concept that Red Dead Redemption flaunted, this is likely the next best thing if you're looking for some interactive fun within the Old West.

The gunplay gives off satisfying audio/visual punches, the AI is solid (Hard and True West will give you a pretty decent challenge at the very least), the visuals are surprisingly sharp and detailed (though it's still not the prettiest game you've ever seen, exactly), and it boasts an ambitious and (mostly) successful gun duel mechanic. Hell, there's even a whole separate endurance mode catered to it. It's an excellent concentration exercise.

Equally as creative is how the great narration can alter the game in a quick pinch, even during mid-combat.

Character B: You sayin' they were Indians?"

Narrator: "No. I said they attacked me Indian /style/."

And

Man. That is satisfying!

This is most definitely a shooter on rails.  But unlike many of the other modern FPSes that place the player on rails, this one is done right.  Call of Juarrez: Gunslinger bleeds style.  It sets out to guide the player through an entertaining FPS experience rife with cinematic set pieces, plenty of humor, and a metric buttload of style.  It pulls it off in spades.  I honestly have not had so much fun in a rails-style shooter in over a decade!

At first I had no intention to play this mainly due to the fact that it is set in the west, which is something I am not really fond of. But I have changed my mind after playing it. Other than it is a fun FPS game, what mainly matters is the humour. Love the narration throughout the game. It is not just run around and shoot things but LISTEN and shoot things.

Another point is the scenery. The game is beautiful in that aspect.

The game modes are interesting too. You have the choice to either pick up the story and play or just spare 10-15 minutes and play some quick mini game.

I recommend this game but the only problem is that I felt it was a little short. But again, it is more than enough for the price.
This game was such a surprise! I had so much fun. The only downside is that it has a very short campaign.

For any western-lover or plain FPS fan, this game is ESSENTIAL to your library of games. The game is completely linear but don't let that put you off as it's been crafted perfectly in terms of set-pieces, level design and just the look. Talking of the look, this is a beautiful game. (even with the kinda cell-shaded look around everything) It's highly stylized, colourful, and authentic. The game pulls you into this rich world and doesn't let go, it oozes style and personality.

The weapons look, sound and most importantly; FEEL fantastic in this game. The gunplay is satisfying as hell. The recoil in each weapon is strong and the kick gives you the visual feedback you need to place your shots on target correctly. As you get more skilled with your weapon of choice you'll get used to the recoil and later on through levelling up you can obtain a higher-performance version of your weapon.

There is a small variety of guns in the game but don't see that as a negative point. Each gun has a unique purpose and aren't watered down unlike other games where there are about 30 guns and they all roughly feel the same. As the game progresses you'll probably find a few favourite weapons that fit your play style and stick with them though you can mix and match as you please.

Same goes for the skills. You can unlock abilities/skills through levelling up. (which is fast and fun in this game, not a chore) You can put a point into the skill you believe fits your playstyle best in one of the three trees, but you can also put points into the others to make your original skills more effective! Ranging from accuracy to faster combo-chaining.

This game is arcade-like in terms of being able to earn combos, you're rewarded for trick shots (Headshots, Piercing shots, Long-Range shots etc) and as well as being fun as hell they will bag you a lot of points which will move you higher up the leaderboard if you're into that kinda thing, if not, simply ignore it! Points also go towards filling up your Focus gauge, which allows you to go into slow-mo when in emergencies and will highlight enemies in red. Use it wisely as it runs out fast, though you can turn it on and off anytime you wish.

The story in this game actually surprised me with its quality. There are a twists and turns along the way, you'll meet some of the most notorious people in the West along the way as allies and enemies. Gunslinger also has a BRILLIANT sense of humour! From the characters relations with each other, to the occasional 4th wall breaking.

This game it utterly fantastic and although you may complete it within anywhere from I'd say... 7-10 hours. The game has a lot of replay value. Going back to finish off the skills/abilities I missed, messing around with new playstyles, completing the harder difficulties, a completely seperate arcade score-attack mode with its own seperate leaderboards, the dueling challenge and last but not least the collectibles!

Which are ACTUALLY good in this game, to which I was immensely surprised. Usually a collectible is some useless piece of junk you pick up for the sake of it being hidden. But in Gunslinger the collectibles are a Poker card. Each one has a little slice of history from the West with photos and theories behind some of the more mysterious ones which made me genuinely give a damn about collecting them! Not too hard to find and rewarding for finding them!




This game is a STEAL for £12!! ($20-25ish?? lol) I would of happily bought if for more! Don't miss out on this! This game has been overlooked by a lot of players but definetely deserves a chance! Get the demo first if you don't feel confident enough, I guarantee you'll fall in love with this game. I recommend this game to everyone!

P.S. - The dueling is badass. (couldn't find anywhere else to say that!)
One of the best stories I ahve ever heard, and fun/exciting gameplay to boot

reviewText:
What Call of Juarez Gunslinger inspires in me is the competitiveness of the old school arcade shooters. Gunslinger offers three modes; story mode and arcade mode and duel mode. Duel mode is mostly forgettable with a minigame style showdown.

It is the arcade mode and story mode that is the standout of the game. For me, Arcade mode alone makes this game worth it. The game is semi-fast paced point-based first person shooter. In arcade mode, shooting enemies yields points. Shooting enemies in the head, yields more points. Shooting enemies in succession yields multipliers, which yields even more points. Points galore! Yes, the arcade mode is about getting the highest score possible and this really makes the game competitive especially for those perfectionists and competitive gamers.

The story mode is an added benefit. The story itself is surprisingly good, offering a unique storytelling style. Without spoiling it, it will definitely keep you entertained and even a few chuckles along the way.

If I had a minor complaint, it would be that the arcade mode stages are all based on the stages from the Story mode. It would've been nice to have a larger variety of stages not already seen from the story mode. But this is a minor complaint, and doesn't detract from the fact that this game is such a solid shooter.

The game's gimmick is also a bullet time style power that slows everyone down. Nothing innovative in this aspect, but the gunplay makes this game highly satisfying to play. For the low price point, you will certainly get your money's worth for it.

like many of you when I saw a new Call of Jaurez game I sighed. The Cartel had poisoned the otherwise great series for me. I loved the originals and Bound in Blood was a hidden gem for the 360 and ps3. But when I saw this game I thought they were going to attempt another Call of Jaurez: Modern Warfare" type thing. Boy was I wrong. Using cell shaded graphics the whole story is told like a beautiful comic book. and the gameplay was smoother then ever. Every gun feels like it's supposed to. If you want to relive the glory days of this franchise or you are a newcomer you should pick this game up."
It`s all true! I played it with my own hands! D:
It`s all true! I played it with my own hands! D:

Fortunately Techland returned back to the roots with Call of Juarez: Gunslinger!

I like the 'light' comic style, the soundtrack and syncronisation, an unused wild west setting, features like bullet time (concentration), the possibility to 'escape' death and the exciting duels.
You can also specialize in different skilltrees and unlock some useful skills.

The story isn't as good as in Call of Juarez and Call of Juarez: Bound in Blood but I really like the kind of storytelling. You're playing the memories of an old man sitting in a saloon talking about his adventures. This leads to some suprises, like playing a part again in a different way.

If you can live with linear (sometimes partly recycled) levels and a short storymode, it's worth a look!

Beautiful graphics, fast and adrenalin-pumping gameplay, perfect narration. And it all covered in the Wild West with all of it's menacing characters.


9/10  Worth every penny.

reviewText:
Fun western game. Play as a dual-wielding gunslinger or rifleman or shotgunner (or a combination of the three!) shooting anything in your way. The concentration system is good, and makes for some powerful fury to be built as one climbs to higher combos.

Music suits the game nicely, though there was no track that stood out to me.

The story in it's original entirety took my 4 hours to beat, though there are collectibles and two other modes (arcade and duel) as well as a new game plus with extra difficculties so points must be given for replayability.

All in all, I'm happy I bought this game, and am happier that I've played through it at least once. Though, if you're going to get the game, make sure to pick it up during a sale. For it's original price, it's not worth it unless you push yourself through all the different modes.

The Pros, The Cons, and the Game
Pros
-Great Storytelling
-Smooth Gameplay
-Beautiful Cel-Shaded World
-Extremely Fun
-Smart AI
-Amazing Immersive Soundtrack
-Detailed Facts about Historical Events/Places/People
-Interesting True West Difficulty (No Huds or Crosshair)
Cons
-Story is Too Short
-Melee is Essentially Useless
-Becomes repetitive after some time
The Game
Overall I rate it a 10/10 for it's amazing landscapes and graphics, immersive soundtrack and fast-paced, realistic gunfights.
