reviewText:
Call of Juarez is a very good action packed old western game.
This game is very unknown but its worth the money.

8/10

Fast paced, stylish and satisfying first person shooter. Like a movie of Quentin Tarantino's as a game.

The game begins as the main character enters a saloon and sits down with a few people to tell them a story about his adventures, as the game itself is the story being told. The main character keeps narrating the story throughout the game, and the people sitting with him talk as well, so in a way you are following two stories at the same time. What makes it really interesting, is that the interraction between the story-teller and the listeners sometimes affect your surroundings and the events in the game, keeping it interesting and full of surprises. So story-wise, the game is excellent.

The visual style of the game is very stylish, comic-like and gritty. There's a lot of blood, just like you'd expect. The music, the sound effects and the voice acting are all excellent and complement that certain wild west feel.

The controls are smooth and responsive, and shooting enemies is satisfying. There are three weapon classes for you to select depending on your preferred playstyle. The game has some well implemented quicktime events.

I completed the game on Hard difficulty setting, and I think it was sometimes hard to follow the narrative in a tight spot as you try to survive, but I don't think it should be passed as a critique. There were also a couple of moments that, in my opinion, required more trial and error than good reflexes and timing. I encountered a few minor bugs in the game, but nothing that would affect the gameplay experience. The game is a bit short, but one hell of a ride.

If you get it for about 10 euros (or dollars) or even less, it's definitely worth it.

As a bonus note: It's almost like playing a modern version of Sunset Riders.

If you like western movies, shooting and a nice story the 'Call of Juarez' series is right up your *******.  It's just plain old western fun. Shooting bad guys and indians for the wrong reasons.....and then kill some more. Love it!\n\nFor me it's important that the 'feel' of the guns and rifels in games like this is good. That changing weapons makes a difference and that it's fun to pull the trigger and reload to give the bad guys some hell. The Arcade style doesn't bother me a bit with this kind of games. Lots of fun.

The Pros, The Cons, and the Game
Pros
-Great Storytelling
-Smooth Gameplay
-Beautiful Cel-Shaded World
-Extremely Fun
-Smart AI
-Amazing Immersive Soundtrack
-Detailed Facts about Historical Events/Places/People
-Interesting True West Difficulty (No Huds or Crosshair)
Cons
-Story is Too Short
-Melee is Essentially Useless
-Becomes repetitive after some time
The Game
Overall I rate it a 10/10 for it's amazing landscapes and graphics, immersive soundtrack and fast-paced, realistic gunfights.
Keep on slinging cowboys...keep on slinging...

This game is a great game. Starting from the story which is interesting all the way to the art style and the gameplay.
The gameplay consists of a lot of shoot outs with a touch of slowing the time down and achieving as many kills as possible for the duration of the slow down in order to achieve high scores. Then at the end of each chapter you'll encounter boss fights. Many of those bosss fights consist of a duel, in which you need to draw your weapon in a blink on an eye and time your moves as well as precisly aligne your mouse. It is a very interesting concept.
The game has lots of replay value and include three modes. The Arcade, the Story and the duel modes. Even if the main story is short the adiitonal mmodes are fun to play and try to compete for the highest score in the leaderboards.
It is a great arcade game.

- Great visual presentation
- Great variety of modes to play
- Story and rank up system
- Big replay value
Bad:

- The constant forced pauses between shoot outs in the main story mode can be annoying

reviewText:
What Call of Juarez Gunslinger inspires in me is the competitiveness of the old school arcade shooters. Gunslinger offers three modes; story mode and arcade mode and duel mode. Duel mode is mostly forgettable with a minigame style showdown.

It is the arcade mode and story mode that is the standout of the game. For me, Arcade mode alone makes this game worth it. The game is semi-fast paced point-based first person shooter. In arcade mode, shooting enemies yields points. Shooting enemies in the head, yields more points. Shooting enemies in succession yields multipliers, which yields even more points. Points galore! Yes, the arcade mode is about getting the highest score possible and this really makes the game competitive especially for those perfectionists and competitive gamers.

The story mode is an added benefit. The story itself is surprisingly good, offering a unique storytelling style. Without spoiling it, it will definitely keep you entertained and even a few chuckles along the way.

If I had a minor complaint, it would be that the arcade mode stages are all based on the stages from the Story mode. It would've been nice to have a larger variety of stages not already seen from the story mode. But this is a minor complaint, and doesn't detract from the fact that this game is such a solid shooter.

The game's gimmick is also a bullet time style power that slows everyone down. Nothing innovative in this aspect, but the gunplay makes this game highly satisfying to play. For the low price point, you will certainly get your money's worth for it.
Silas Greaves' stories seem unbelievable. He claims he was present at key moments in American Western history, but is not remembered.

If you hate UPlay, do not fear! Although this is an Ubisoft game, it launches strictly from Steam alone. Most of all, if you love games of skill, and especially if you love shooters, do not pass up this game!

This is truly excellent. In one sense, it's a shooter stripped of the fat of a modern FPS - an almost arcade experience. But it's also got significant depth to it, introducing some rather wonderful gameplay aspects and accompanied by some nicely pitched humour.

It's the perfect price for what you'll get: a good 9 hours of the story mode, which has plenty of replay potential, but also two more modes to enjoy. It'll give you as much entertainment as other games three or four times that price, and the production quality is absolutely top notch. Buy it, love it.

The good:
- Graphics are very detailed
- Story Mode has an engaging story
- Gameplay is challenging and entertaining
- Arcade Mode is exciting

The bad:
- No multiplayer
- Difficult to navigate in some levels because of unlite areas

reviewText:
Short Version: Very Fun but linear, and only ~10 hours. Not graphically fantastic, but great artstyle. Guns all feel nice, as well as the environments. Enemies are varied, as well as bosses. Duelling is difficult, but often far between luckily, and each level feels different. 8/10, very very fun way to kill 10 hours, and good replayability.

Call of Juarez: Gunslinger (or Gunslinger from now on) is effectively a rail shooter, so gameplay wise it's not particularly innovative. In short, follow the path, shoot the dudes, rinse and repeat. The western theme makes for some great style, especially in Gunslinger's comic book-esq Artstyle and some interesting levels, such as those in a Goldmine, a Swamp, and a whole-town shootout to name a few. There's a few different guns from which to choose from, you get a primary weapon, Double-Barreled Shotgun or Rifle, and a secondary which you can single or dual wield from the short-ranged Quickshooter or Sawn-Off Shotgun, or the mid-ranged Six-Shooter or the long-ranged Ranger, in addition to some Dynamite on later levels. There's a skillpoint system, and generally you'll level up once a level or so, and there's a variety of upgrades for Short Range, Mid Range and Long Ranged combat with some Weapon Upgrades when you've invested enough points. Towards the end, you may feel a bit overpowered, especially with a new game + option, but Gunslinger's difficulty isn't particularly high to begin with, except for the totally evil duelling, where you need about 3 eyes just to be able to do it decently, and feels a bit token just because it's a Wild West themed game. In addition to your guns and dynamite, Gunslinger also gives you two extra toys: Sense of Death, and Concentration. Concentration is bullet time, but is very useful when things get a bit hectic. Sense of Death has a 30 second recharge that allows you to dodge a lethal bullet if you lean out of it's way. Useful certainly, but you'll probably die a lot from misjudgement.

While Gunslinger isn't particularly innovative or exciting in Gameplay, it makes up for it, strangely enough, in story. Gunslinger follows an old man who wonders into a Saloon of a sleepy town one day, claiming to be the legendary Bounty Hunter, Boba Fe-I MEAN Silas Greaves. The alleged Mr. Greaves then tells some stories from his Bounty Hunting days to the few folks in the saloon, which are the levels we play in game. Where Gunslinger really makes this effective is some excellent narration, seriously the voice acting is beautiful, take my word on it. But Gunslinger has another ace up it's sleeve. The narration follows you outside the cutscenes to the levels, and on several occasions, time will rewind, the level reorganise and plot details change, it's some excellent storytelling.

But as usual, Gunslinger is not perfect. It's not particularly difficult, and the extra ammo upgrades are kind of useless as you get showered in ammo. A lot of enemies are very difficult to see, and misjudgement from sense of death will be a pain in the ♥♥♥♥. The duelling system is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and the final 'plot twist' is a bit predictable.

While not the greatest game ever, Gunslinger is probably the most fun I've ever had with a game. Not only is it an excellent narritive experience, but it's just fun in a kind of mental/badass way. How many games can you name where you can become a magical shotgun wizard, where you dual-wield Sawn-Off Shotguns, with no reloads and increased damage in bullet time mode, and clear out an entire bank of thugs in the middle of a whole-town shootout? None other, than Call of Juarez: Gunslinger.

8/10 - Not particularly innovative, some dodgy textures here and there, and a poor duelling system. But some simple and rewarding gameplay combined with beautiful setting and level design.

Coming from a relatively not well know franchise, Call of Juarez Gunslinger comes in guns blazing. Set in the Old West, you take on the role as Silas Greaves as you take on legendary outlaws as you try to make things right in the world. The way the story is told is the narrator is Silas Greaves and he takes you through the story. The story is told in real time so anything Silas will say will happen, whether or not it makes sense. This way of telling the story is unique and it works.

The gameplay is tight and flows well. The game features a combo system that rewards quick kills and precision aiming. As you earn xp you level up and you unlock perks. If you unlock enough perks in that category you get a legendary weapon. The game also features arcade mode which is certain sections of story in which your objective is to score as much points as possible. The last mode is Duels, where you go through 15 duels and you try to score as much points as possible.

There are some gripes I have with this game is that to change the FOV you have to go into Video.scr to change it. Not many people are aware of this. The AI isnt the best, they just spawn and shoot you. I have experienced a couple crashes with the game.

If you are a fan of first person shooters get this, if you like Wild West shooters definitely get this.


To change the FOV

1) Go to C:\Users\YOURNAMEHERE\AppData\Local	ech­land\cojgunslinger\out\Settings
2) Open Video.scr with notepad
3) Add the following 2 lines to the bottom of the list

ForcedHorzFov(INSERT FOV NUMBER HERE BETWEEN 80-110)
DisableScreenBorder()

reviewText: Short and sweet, like my ♥♥♥♥.

Masterful, and Highly Underrated
Call of Juarez Gunslinger was an entertaining ride from start to finish. This must have been said at least 100 times by now, but i felt like adding my own words into the pot (so to speak). The game follows the adventures (or misadventures) of Silas Greaves. The whole game essentially is Silas in a bar recalling his adventures of years gone by. Of course, the whole game inst just a cutscene, you actually get to play in Silas' stories as he tells them. Many famous outlaws of the Wild West, such as Jesse James and Billy the Kid. The game really shines gameplay-wise. There's no complicated game mechanics, nor a deep levelling system. Gunplay is really well done and the basic levelling system compliments it nicely. The game took me around 7 (ish) hours to complete and is well worth the asking price (even better when it's on sale!)

Performance
This game originally came out a few years ago, so i can't say much about day one. I managed to attain a locked 60fps 95% of the time in 1440p (with a GTX 960).

Overall, I'd give this game a 9/10 | Highly Recommend

Call of Juarez Gunslinger was so insanely fun, bought it for $1 during a humble bundle and could have easily spent $10 and been happy. reviewText: An FPS Western (possibly the only one in years) about taking every modern advancement, technology, and trend and applying it to a cartoon parody of the Wild West in an utterly perfect way. If you have the slightest interest in action games, shooters, artistic visuals, or Ye Olde West (educational facts about the Wild West are collectibles), this game is perfect for you. There are two singleplayer modes: Campaign, where you hear a drunken old man tell his life story and then shoot someone right in the bar in full view of like ten people, and Arcade, where you re-enact all of your favorite Matrix/ Equilibrium/ Die Hard/ Expendables/ Terminator/ Robocop scenes in the desert with revolvers and double-barrel shotguns as you dodge bullets, enter bullet-time, hammer fire revolvers, shoot explosive barrels, destroy cover, dual-weild pistols, and THROW DYNAMITE THAT TURNS INTO THREE DYNAMITES WHICH YOU CAN THEN SHOOT MID-AIR. Also, Duels mode, if you couldn't get enough of a minigame about watching your own and other people's hands. This is literally my favorite game of all time, second only to a game that did everything Undertale did... 3 years before Undertale was released. Play this game, it deserves more recognition!
It's very simple - wild wild west, nothing but the best. :)

reviewText: just completed the story mode and held back on this short review until then.\n\nits rare these days that i complete a game, time, too many distractions but.... i absolutely loved every single minute of this; it isnt a massively long game, but sometimes thats just all u need. the story and music is superb all the way thru - if your a fan of westerns you need this game in your life.

I gotta say, I've been a sucker for games in the west ever since I first played GUN. While Red Dead and Bound in Blood took a serious and darker tone to the frontier, the Arcade gameplay and outrageous gunfights bring a bit of humor, and style to the west again. If you liked The Lone Ranger, you'll love Gunslinger. Not to mention it's amazing way of storytelling and unique cel-shaded graphics.

Set in the old west the story follows the life of a bounty hunter named Silas Greaves. The main storyline of the game is narrated by Silas as an old man in a run down salon. As an interesting mechanic the game can change based on the narration, some of these changes are amusing. Often you will play a mission as one of your audience explains the well known story only to then have to replay the same mission as Greaves say Well that's an interesting story but what happened was....."\n\nGameplay wise it is a very linear game and is a sequence of shooting galleries. Reach an area and a number of enemies will spawn and rush you. You have 3 main weapons and upgrade trees
recommended: rifle and shotgun. Kills also earn concentration which can initiate a 'bullet time' slowdown allowing you to target and fire at multiple enemies. The boss fights are a mix between bulletsponges and duels
hoursPlayed: The duels are by far the best of these. I find the difficulty of the duels to be just right
voteText: often I would require a couple of attempts to complete but sometimes succeeded in the first attempt.\n\nOutside of the storyline there is also a couple of leaderboard style game modes. Arcade which is a level you need to clear with the highest score possible. Score is a combination of points for chaining kills and things like headshots and time to complete. There is also a pure dual mode where you need to complete 15 duels with 5 lives. The main game is still the main draw card but they additional modes are fun."

The only right way to play this game is to load up the soundtrack of your favorite spaghetti western and play it over this game.\n\nBut actually this is probably THE BEST FPS western out there. It draws heavily on the old spaghetti westerns and John Wayne movies. Overall this is a must for truly any Western fan or FPS enthusiast.

An absolutely amazingly well done shooter that holds up to the test of time. Someone who loved Wild West American history put their heart and soul into this game. On the surface it's your typical shoot'em'up. Shoot, shoot, shoot, reload, and shoot some more--my favorite. Of course, it sports a Wild West Americana theme through the story telling of Silas Greaves.\n\nThe people in the story are actually real people. There's history and speculation behind these people back when we weren't so great at logging our past. This allows the story teller to stretch the truth as we see our plot unfold. Secret collectables known as nuggets of truth" reveal factual history on these characters and more
date: so it's also educational and full of intrigue.\n\nThe combat is solid. I wasn't a big fan of the quickdraw segments. I had to repeat these a lot because you have to keep track of three things at once while trying to pop the bad guy. Normal combat is visceral and action packed! Bad guys have great aim
recommended: though they don't flank around too much. They use cover and reload appropriately. Your "health" meter is very well represented by paper tears on your screen that heal over time. Weapons feel powerful and kinetic. There's very little variety
hoursPlayed: unfortunately. Three revolvers
helpfulPercent: and two rifles. There's a level-up mechanic in the form of skills. Unfortunately shotguns are way too limited and the gunslinger tree focuses too much on spray-and-pray
votesHelpful:
so if you want to play this game on the hardest difficulty you are going to default to "Ranger" and focus on longrange combat and precision.

The game has a points system for gaining experience in the same way that Bulletstorm does. The "cheat death" mechanic is a lot like Max Payne. You get to see who's about to gank you and you can turn the tables and get yourself back in the fight.

The game isn't realistic by any means
votesTotal: but that's what makes it such a fun shooter. If you like FPS games and Western themes then you need to give this game a try."

I've played through this game almost 4 times. I love the gunplay in this game, the weapons are so satisfying to use. I could play through using just dual revolvers. I played through a second time trying to only use the shotgun, thunderous explosions everytime you fire. The guns look good, sound good, and feel good to use. There are 2 weapons slots with one having a couple flavors of revolvers and sawed-off and the other having a rifle or shotgun. You get xp and xp multipliers for different kinds of kills that let you buy new abilities, upgrades, and passives. Good story too, the narration was really well done and cheesy in a good way at parts. I was shocked at how much I enjoyed this game when I got it for pc and surprised again at how much I'm enjoying it after it was free with ps+ a couple of weeks ago.

A great salavage. I've only played the second game in the series before this but as I heard the third game Call of Juarez cartel wasn't a great game. This game on the otherhand takes the series back to it's old west roots although it ditches the characters of the first two games for a totally new bend.

This game focuses on an old washed up gunslinger spinning tales for booze in a Kansas bar who according to his own tales has shot down more men than... shoot, I don't think anyone has as high a body count as Silus Greaves claims. The story is mostly a tale of revenge as he hunts for a man who robbed and killed both his brothers and left him for dead with a rope necktie and a coin in his mouth so they can't say I left you with nothing"

Do NOT be fooled by this games lower price tag

reviewText: I loved every minut of this game, story mode is short but it's sooo good, I'd like to to shake hands with the developers and sayu good job:) I think this is a masterpiece
Great game. Great story.

Coming from a relatively not well know franchise, Call of Juarez Gunslinger comes in guns blazing. Set in the Old West, you take on the role as Silas Greaves as you take on legendary outlaws as you try to make things right in the world. The way the story is told is the narrator is Silas Greaves and he takes you through the story. The story is told in real time so anything Silas will say will happen, whether or not it makes sense. This way of telling the story is unique and it works.

The gameplay is tight and flows well. The game features a combo system that rewards quick kills and precision aiming. As you earn xp you level up and you unlock perks. If you unlock enough perks in that category you get a legendary weapon. The game also features arcade mode which is certain sections of story in which your objective is to score as much points as possible. The last mode is Duels, where you go through 15 duels and you try to score as much points as possible.

There are some gripes I have with this game is that to change the FOV you have to go into Video.scr to change it. Not many people are aware of this. The AI isnt the best, they just spawn and shoot you. I have experienced a couple crashes with the game.

If you are a fan of first person shooters get this, if you like Wild West shooters definitely get this.


To change the FOV

1) Go to C:\Users\YOURNAMEHERE\AppData\Local	ech­land\cojgunslinger\out\Settings
2) Open Video.scr with notepad
3) Add the following 2 lines to the bottom of the list

ForcedHorzFov(INSERT FOV NUMBER HERE BETWEEN 80-110)
DisableScreenBorder()

Has an interesting story which makes full use of the fact it's narration from a storyteller in a bar, but after you finish the story there are other cool modes like arcade levels where you race to build up an awesome combo and also try and shoot your way through duels, whether honourably or dishonourably.
Has a very good story, but the endind(s) are the best part. The narration definitely makes up for the Story Rich" attribute
date: but the game is'nt as "Open World" as you would think. In most cases it's an option of two or three different paths
recommended: or certain zones with a slightly open area."

Call of Juarez: Gunslinger is a first-person shooter which heavily trives on old Westerns tropes and cliché to tell the story of Silas Graves, a bounty hunter on a quest for revenge, without taking itself too seriously.\nThe game actually encourages the player to take precise shoots and off the various enemies in the most unortodox ways: given the score mechanic, the more points you can earn for a series of stylish kills the more experience you can gain, the more abilities/perks/unlocked weapons you can secure for your character and the longer you can use the bullet time feature (Concentration). The gameplay is rendered even more fun by a great enemy variety and a pletora of combat techniques. There is even a dedicated arcade mode with the purpose of achieving the highest score possible out of waves after waves of enemies.\nGunslinger's plot is told in a story within a story" fashion
date: with Silas telling his tales to a bunch of costumers in a saloon. The game actually takes advantage of this by using unexpected turns of events justifyed by how Silas is actually reporting the story
recommended: with paths often appearing out of thin air because Silas just remembered about them or the time being rewinded to tell the tale in a different light. Such events are always amusing.\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: Call of Juarez: Gunslinger is a cheap and charming title. There is no harm in trying it. Not at all."

Call of Juarez: Gunslinger[en.wikipedia.org]


Developer: Techland[en.wikipedia.org]
Publisher: Ubisoft[en.wikipedia.org]
Release Date: May 23, 2013
Genre: First-Person Shooter[en.wikipedia.org]

GameplayCall of Juarez: Gunslinger features fast paced and unique first person shooter gameplay. With the addition of combat-based quicktime events, the gameplay feels smooth and genuine. In addition to fun gunplay, Techland provides a great progression system for the combat. Players can choose to advance in skill from one of three perk trees. Each perk gained  not only enhances the player's combat ability, but also provides a feeling of accomplishment. Along with the refined nature of progression, the firefights in this game have an old-school" type feeling that fans of Doom or Quake will notice. The game encourages running while firing as there is no cover system and a large amount of enemies. The game features the standard health and armor bar
date: but also features a regenerating health system. Despite it's modern twist on an old genre
recommended: Call of Juarez: Gunslinger succeeds in providing a genuinely challenging FPS experience.\n\nGraphicsFor it's time of release
hoursPlayed: the game exhibits great visuals and performance. While the game is heavily stylized
voteText: it still looks great and can run perfectly on most modern machines. I was able to run the game at 4K with sweetfx installed while maintaining a solid 60 FPS. That says a lot about the game's optimized state as I am using a GTX 970

reviewText:
Call of Juarez Gunslinger is an FPS based on the Wild West, a title that was released as a digital download only, and priced as an indie game at launch, (15$ is an absolute steal) but with AAA production values.
After the underwhelming critical response to Call of Juarez The Cartel, developer Techland and publisher Ubisoft went back to the drawing board and revived a franchise many thought would never be relevant again, and for all intents and purposes, they managed to pull it off, Call of Juarez Gunslinger is a great Call of Juarez title, and an amazing shooter in it's own right.

The game has 3 main play modes, Story, Arcade and Duel. Story mode is the main one in the game, you play as Silas Greaves a bounty Hunter who has just arrived to a bar in Abilene, Texas and starts telling his life story to a few people at the local saloon, for a few free drinks. He tells about how he met Billy The Kid, Johnny Ringo, Sundance Kid, Butch Cassidy and other famous Wild West legends. The game's story and narration is told in a very different way than any other game, as you play the levels Silas himself is telling the story as he remembers it, and it creates a unique gaming experience in the sense that as you play a level, you hear him and the people around him, telling what happened and asking how the events took place. It is simple and it makes for a few twists to the story in the levels in real time, when Silas tells something that sounds almost impossible, it usually is, and he then tells the story how it actually happened" making you play some levels in completely different ways. It is an interesting mechanic
date: and quite unique in how it presents the story to the player.\n\nArcade mode is all about getting through levels as fast as you can and rack up the most amount of points possible
recommended: it is incredibly fun to play and the combo system(which also exists in the story) for taking down enemies works amazingly well and is very rewarding.\n\nDuel is a mode that allows you to play
hoursPlayed: or replay the Duels from the main story. It is what makes this game feel like it actually takes place in the Wild West
voteText: and it's also what made Call of Juarez unique to begin with. It is basically a 1 on 1 (sometimes 1 on 2) standout like you see in most Westerns worthy of that name
helpfulPercent: where the camera is focusing on your enemy from a behind your gun perspective and you need to focus and adjust the weapon draw speed to succeed. You will need fast reflexes to win these duels
votesHelpful: and they are incredibly gratifying
votesTotal: and fun to play.\n\nThe visuals and audio in the game are quite amazing
votesFunny: even more so considering this is not a full budget AAA game. The game's engine is Techland's proprietary Chrome Engine 5
commentsCount: an engine used in Dead Island and Dead Island Riptide for example
column16: and it uses a cel-shaded effect that makes the game look quite unique. It is similar in it's looks to the style Borderlands uses
column17: although different enough to stand out on it's own. It is violent and bloody
column18: and everything on screen looks great and plays fast. The music is one of the best parts of the game
column19: it sets the mood quite well
column20: and they are essencial to the experience in the way it works together with the visuals
column21: the presentation and the overall feel of the game. Call of Juarez is in more ways than one
column22: a true homage to the Wild West

reviewText: Back in summer 2009 COJ BiB was released. I got a bunch of friends to join with me on a two week analization on Stinking Springs. Players would join, get domed, and leave. It was the most fun I've had killing people online in a long time. Oh yeah this game is wildly fun YEEE HAWWWW!

Alright it's time rewrite History....now that history test you got next week won't seem to hard will it? This game is one very excellent FPS i have played in a while! With awesome gameplay, nice detailing, Blood....a lot of blood (Especailly if you get a headshot which is extremely satisfying), and a funny & clever storytelling, It will make you feel like that Cowboy Legend you've been striving to be!

[Western Themed] First-Person Shooter.

You play as the badass Silas Greaves, a bounty hunter with a very long list of hits and a very long list of stories to tell.

The graphics look like they were ripped right out of a story book, and in the most heart-warming way. You can tell Techland put a lot of love into this project, because it shows every step of the way.

The gameplay setting takes place in the past, while the narration takes place in the present as he tells his epic stories to some teenagers at a bar. This let the developers have some fun with the story-telling mechanics, with frequent rewinds and misinformation, making for longer gameplay. You can collect artifacts to read the true historical facts if you wish.

The gameplay is, for the most part, like most first person shooters. But CoJG comes with a fresh twist on gunplay. While old mechanics like the concentration gauge make a warm return, you can now come face to face with an outlaw for a quick-draw duel. Very groovy mechanic, and it definitely makes the whole western theme feel extra solid. You can carry two single handle weapons such as pistols or sawn-offs, as well as a double handed weapon like a rife or shotgun. This installment in the franchise plays a little differently from it's predecessors in the sense that it has an arcade feel to it. Every shot has skill points attached to it, which gains experience points to upgrade your character the way you play. The skill tree is divided into three classes: Gunslinger, Ranger, & Trapper - giving you the power over how to evolve your character.

Normal, Hard, and True West difficulty settings. New game plus is unlocked once completed.

10/10

V.good gameplay
Amazing storyline
arcade mode give u alot of fun and challenges

I was never into western gun fight cowboy themes. To be clear, I was more leaned to dislike. However, this game changed my mind. ‘Silas Greaves’ changed my mind, Hahaha. Handling dual pistols, taking down enemies far away with rifles, earning xp to become more skillful gunman of the west, all for you to enjoy the spirit of western pioneer age. Have fun.

+) Fun Aiming.

-) I think when you upgrade your skills to more fine guns, you should always be able to use that.

This truly is one of the greatest games I have ever played

Yet I completely forgot about it after I played it the first time

Seriously it's got the classic western movie clichè of having a story based largely on vengance, and even though most of
the cutscenes are through drawings of 6 people in a bar and 1 of them telling the story of how he became the most famed bounty hunter in the land

They convey a story in a way only truly matched by Westerado: Double Barreled or Brothers In Arms. And they have new and interesting ways of building the level, and a definate story that puts a 3rd person view on the western shooter. Like Brothers In Arms: Earned In Blood did with the war game genrà. But in a subtle and truly haunting way.

The jumping being off as hell I definetally reccomend this game to people who love FEELING like they can kill thousands single handedly.

The art is celshaded, and despite the horrible border around your view, the look of the game is something we haven't seen before. The Borderlands celshaded look added to a western and thrown in some of the most colourful blood I have ever seen

Dispatching of enemies is easy and fun but also the regeneration ability doesn't make it feel like you're cheating. The duels are somehow easy and difficult at the same time and they switch up how the duel works every other duel and really forces you to pay attention.

If I haven't sold the game to you already, probably the fact that it's for anyone who has hands. As like I said, dispatching of enemies is easy and fun but also challenging. So people who don't really think that much about the story will enjoy it to, unlike those who can't play Life Is Strange without a single explosion happening atleast every 6 seconds will sell it to you.

An amazing game set back in the times of the Wild West.

Missions.

Arcade.

Leaderboards and all that great stuff.

9.5/10.

reviewText: Call of Juarez : Gunslinger is a short but a decent addition to the Call of Juarez franchise. Rich in stories about outlaws and replayability content, this game has a lot to offer considering it's low price. The arcade mode has a competitive and active leaderboard in which players try to become the fastest gun the in the West. reviewText: Techland has such a talented story writer. I've played bound in blood, and it really left me with the feeling that I've played more than just a game. The open world aspect of it was astounding for me back at the day.\nDying light is also one of the best games. While I thought that this gunslinger couldn't be better than the bound in blood because its linear gameplay, its immersive story telling and creative display of the graphics put it on another category and still drives a win for me.\nYou couldn't be wrong buying this game I guess..

Call of Juarez Gunslinger is a Wild West FPS where you take control of Silas Greaves. Greaves is a legendary bounty hunter who has fought the best the Wild West has to offer and in the year 1910 he enters a Saloon in Abilene, Kansas. Greaves tells the patrons of the Saloon about his encounters with the legends of the West and it is these stories that you play.

As a huge fan of Red Dead Redemption searching for more good Western games (something that is seemingly hard to come by) this game delivered a fun burst of Western fun that just makes me want more.

+Great cel shaded graphics
+Incredibly fun gameplay including frequent slow motion segments (bullet-time)
+Good combo system which rewards you for keeping the combo going
+Well designed environments
+Fight some of the best of the West, many of whom will be well-known names if you have an interest in all things Western
+Great skill trees which add more gameplay mechanics and introduce new weapons
+Three different types of main weapon, each with its own playstyle
+Terrific voice acting
+Interesting characters and story made even better by the use of an unreliable narrator
+Super fun boss fights in the form of duels (even a threeway standoff)
+Some good humour every now and then
+Intelligent AI who behave similarly to how you would expect real people to behave, i.e. searching for cover as soon as they are in danger

-Too short, I completed the story in just over 4 hours though there are other game modes

Verdict:
8.5

reviewText: Call of Du...er...Juarez, is a creative take on FPS, you'll have fun with the storyline. I'm yet to finish off the game. All in all, as of yet I'd call this game good.

I can dig it. Very colorful cell-shaded western game. Very arcade-y feel to it. Bullet time has been done before, but it fits in well with this game. I actually got a couple good chuckles out of parts of it. Seemed a lot more light-hearted than the previous Call of Juarezes. Multiple game modes, New Game+, an RPG-like leveling system. Story is told through a bounty hunter that has walked into a bar and is telling a series of stories about his life. Interesting plot twist at the end, with a choice. New Game+ points out bits of the story that may have been overlooked before. Nuggets of Truth are collectibles scattered throughout levels that give bonus experience and reveal information about certain topics such as people and objects in the real old west. Voice acting was top notch, I recognized the guy who voiced the grandpa from the old Ben 10 cartoon series as one of the main characters.\n\nOverall probably an 8/10. Could have been longer, but otherwise a great game.

Its not often a rare gem like this comes to my attension. Thanks to a good friend who unfortunatly doesn't want to experince every bit of this game like I do due to his perefence in difficulty.
Call of Juarez is a Western FPS, Single player and come with Campain (Story mode), Arcade and Quickdraw Duels

Arcade: In this mode you try to go for the highest score while choosing a certain class of weapon. (Gunslinger) Double Quickshooters. Ranger (1 Revolver and a Rifle) and Trapper (Shotgun, Revolver). Your goal is to be a combo master-god and to (or at least attempt) to keep a combo going for as long as possible (perferably start to end of the level for the bigest score multiplyier) All the while trying your best to survive the onlast of of enimies your running into to keep you combo up (Unless in a situation where they are comming to you).
Each class in this mode also have a set of skills that you unlock over time ascoiated with them that will help you imensivly as time goes on. The only problem with the system is the trapper class due the sole reason I CANNOT FIGURE OUT HOW TO KEEP A COMBO WITH A 2 SHOT SLOW REALOADING SHOTGUN" but all that aside with shotgun being my most look down upon weapon in the game.
The other 2 clases are built really well in comparison. Gunslinger is really good at high populated areas where you need to take them out as fast at possible without dieing. and the Ranger is good for when the range of the enimies is to great to take on with a revolver without risking losing your combo taking time to go in closer. Oh noteworthy tip to note
date: Rifle headshots are worth twice in points compare to revolver/quickshooter headshots.\n\nDuels: This mode was desing to forcus the boss battles in the game is a western like fashion. In other words
recommended: its a quickdraw tourniment where the slowest lose. It takes awhile to master since you need to do 3 main things. Line up your target with a very (on purpose) wibbly wobby crosshair that gets smaller more your forcus in. Make sure your hand speed is at the highest by having a balencing minigame est with your hand slowly moving towards your gun to quicken your pull out speed. and lastly if you want to play morally and get achivements like the cools cats do. YOU NEED TO BE THE 2ND ONE TO PULL OUT OF HIS HOLSTER. Unlike the arcade mode

reviewText: An excellent and flavorful game with good storytelling, fluid mechanics and modest but effectively executed ambitions. For the price a must have for fans of FPS and Western experiences.

This is a very good western FPS that takes advantage of its storytelling in ways you don't normally see. It's presented as a recollection of a bounty hunter's life told over some drinks, and the gameplay reflects that. If a detail is wrong, the game will rewind and fix itself. If he talks about something coming from out of nowhere
date: it might actually fall from the skies. It's all rather clever. There's good mechanics at play here too, with an XP and level up system with different skill trees, a combo and focus meter system, a different take on down but not out
recommended: and one on one duels, there's quite a lot here in this 4 hour game. There's also a combo focused arcade mode and a new game +, so I will definitely check both of those out. For FPS fans, this is a great buy at $15.

reviewText:
A brilliant premise, brought to stunning completion thanks to excellent voice acting and a great score. The set-pieces are solid, and the game is the perfect length to remain fun the whole time.

There are some 'Techland' moments in terms of bugs -- if you've played any of their other games, you'll recognize them -- but not even their quality control team were able to bring this down.

If you like shooters at all, do yourself a favour and pick this up. If you like Westerns at all, do yourself a favour and pick this up. Hell, even if you hate video games (and if so, why are you reading Steam reviews?), do yourself a favour and pick this up.

reviewText: I'm not a massive fan of the Old West but this games unique storytelling via almost constant narration and minimal cutscenes is one of the most interesting methods I've encountered in a game. The story itself is isn't award winning material but the way this game presents it certainly elevates it. As for the gameplay it's quite a simplistic but satisfying FPS. The gameplay may get a little repetitive for some but the story and upgrade system is sure to keep things interesting and although there isn't much of a variety of weapons in the game they all get the job done with satisfying impact. Plus you can dual wield Sawn-Off shotguns so...ya know, there's that. The only part of the game I didn't enjoy was the duelling. Now it may be because I sucked at them (and I am a sore loser) but I found that they were... well I just couldn't get the hang of it and found them difficult, especially as they take so damn long and I get incredibly impatient and antsy when I lose- Christ I shouted at my cat for distracting me! But I digress. The soundtrack is also very good, it retains an old west feel while still sounding modern and sets the perfect tone for this game. Now I haven't played any other title in the franchise so I can't judge it as part of a series but as a standalone game I recommend it strongly, especially if you're a fan of the era.

reviewText: Run, shoot, run shoot. Mindless killing for the win - also cowboys. Who the hell doesn't like cowboys?

Its not often a rare gem like this comes to my attension. Thanks to a good friend who unfortunatly doesn't want to experince every bit of this game like I do due to his perefence in difficulty.
Call of Juarez is a Western FPS, Single player and come with Campain (Story mode), Arcade and Quickdraw Duels

Arcade: In this mode you try to go for the highest score while choosing a certain class of weapon. (Gunslinger) Double Quickshooters. Ranger (1 Revolver and a Rifle) and Trapper (Shotgun, Revolver). Your goal is to be a combo master-god and to (or at least attempt) to keep a combo going for as long as possible (perferably start to end of the level for the bigest score multiplyier) All the while trying your best to survive the onlast of of enimies your running into to keep you combo up (Unless in a situation where they are comming to you).
Each class in this mode also have a set of skills that you unlock over time ascoiated with them that will help you imensivly as time goes on. The only problem with the system is the trapper class due the sole reason I CANNOT FIGURE OUT HOW TO KEEP A COMBO WITH A 2 SHOT SLOW REALOADING SHOTGUN" but all that aside with shotgun being my most look down upon weapon in the game.
The other 2 clases are built really well in comparison. Gunslinger is really good at high populated areas where you need to take them out as fast at possible without dieing. and the Ranger is good for when the range of the enimies is to great to take on with a revolver without risking losing your combo taking time to go in closer. Oh noteworthy tip to note
date: Rifle headshots are worth twice in points compare to revolver/quickshooter headshots.\n\nDuels: This mode was desing to forcus the boss battles in the game is a western like fashion. In other words
recommended: its a quickdraw tourniment where the slowest lose. It takes awhile to master since you need to do 3 main things. Line up your target with a very (on purpose) wibbly wobby crosshair that gets smaller more your forcus in. Make sure your hand speed is at the highest by having a balencing minigame est with your hand slowly moving towards your gun to quicken your pull out speed. and lastly if you want to play morally and get achivements like the cools cats do. YOU NEED TO BE THE 2ND ONE TO PULL OUT OF HIS HOLSTER. Unlike the arcade mode

reviewText: A unique and fun gaming experience. The design is awesome. Definitely well worth the money and i'll give this game a 8/10.. BUY IT GOD DAMNIT!

Call of Juarez: Gunslinger[en.wikipedia.org]


Developer: Techland[en.wikipedia.org]
Publisher: Ubisoft[en.wikipedia.org]
Release Date: May 23, 2013
Genre: First-Person Shooter[en.wikipedia.org]

GameplayCall of Juarez: Gunslinger features fast paced and unique first person shooter gameplay. With the addition of combat-based quicktime events, the gameplay feels smooth and genuine. In addition to fun gunplay, Techland provides a great progression system for the combat. Players can choose to advance in skill from one of three perk trees. Each perk gained  not only enhances the player's combat ability, but also provides a feeling of accomplishment. Along with the refined nature of progression, the firefights in this game have an old-school" type feeling that fans of Doom or Quake will notice. The game encourages running while firing as there is no cover system and a large amount of enemies. The game features the standard health and armor bar
date: but also features a regenerating health system. Despite it's modern twist on an old genre
recommended: Call of Juarez: Gunslinger succeeds in providing a genuinely challenging FPS experience.\n\nGraphicsFor it's time of release
hoursPlayed: the game exhibits great visuals and performance. While the game is heavily stylized

reviewText:
As a person who has always enjoyed a good western i have to say i had alot of fun with this game i cannot say i am familiar with the Call of Juarez series as a whole but i decided to buy this one and have found it to be very refreshing and enjoyable its not that often that you see many western games around so for a start i would recommend this game for a change of pace from the norm of games. Call of Jaurez Gunslinger has you take up the Bounty Hunting life of Silas Greaves who is equally skilled at Gunslinger and telling a good story in the local Saloon while downing a shot of Whisky.

Right away what i liked was the unique story telling approach that this game took with Silas telling his listeners what was happening and you then doing what he was saying and there were times when he would say he did something or fought someone and then the next he explains it differently and it takes you back to do it the next way he explains it. To me this was very different from how most games tell a story of there campaign and i found it very refreshing and interesting and just in general alot of fun.

In terms of actual gameplay its very straightfoward and uses the typical control style of most fps games so it was easy to jump into and start gunning down your foes. There were some really awesome features like dodging bullets and have a quickeye mode allowing you to shoot multiple targets quickly to some there features might seem abit gimicky but i can assure you that it does add some very fun elements to the game and you have to make use of them correctly to get your way through the tough spots.

Another nice feature is the upgrade system instead of just starting of the game and blazing your way through like alot of shooters you are offered to upgrade your character in certain areas like duel wielding pistols or taking a route down the rifle upgrade tree or shotgun this system allows you to develop your character to specilize in a specific are or you can disperse upgrades evenly its entirely up to you so you can go through each playthrough using a different setup for your character. There is also a unique system the game has when you have a classic western gunslinger duel and although the control system isnt perfect and at first is abit hard to get use to the duels are alot of fun in duel mode once you learn how to do them.

To bring up some negatives i was rather disapointed in the limited selection of weapons there are only about 3 pistols a rifle and a shotgun and although you can get upgraded versions of there weapons that have different visuals and amounts power and accuracy they are in essence the same weapons and as a result there isnt alot of variety there. Also even though the story is good to my mind its abit to short i was able to finish it on the standard difficulty in about 5 and a hald hours which is a little to short to my tastes but you could play on higher difficulties to make it more challenging and you could go around gathering all the collectables to increase that game length.

In terms of graphics and visuals its very beautiful with lots of great locations that help drive the story and immerse you in the gameplay ranging from old towns to forests and canyons to fighting in saloons and on trains so its very diverse which is fantastic. Another great feature i like was the addition of historical figures like Billy the Kid Butch Cassidy Sundance Kid and Jesse James and Silas's take on what he says really happens with these characters and his encounters and battles with them.

The Plot does possess a really nice twist to it which was nice when you got to the end and were able to enjoy it to sum up i do recommend this game as it is alot of fun and it does feel like a really great shooter even if it is abit short but i still think its worth it i give it a solid 6.5/10

reviewerDisplayName: A Q U I L A | CSGOCasino.co.uk
reviewText: One of the best games out there, by a ligtyear. The only game I've played through multiple times and one of only maybe two or three I've actually put the effort in to complete in its entirety (only other one I can think of is Arkham Asylum). Incredible game, worth every pound/doll hair.

A fun little game, an FPS that's almost a rail-shooter, with some interesting tweeks to make it enjoyable and Western. The story is pretty good for a shortened game, and the tall tale'ing of the West is alive in the game's narrative. The graphics are almost cell-shaded and the characters are bright and almost cartoon-like. The game won't take you long, but its a good, fun romp for a few hours. Hit it up when its on a deep sale.

It is rather short. But that's not bad at all!!
Best few hours a wild west FPS can get you. And there are challenging different game modes to compare who is the quickest trigger between you, your friends and the steam community. Also there's a great replay factor, because once you've reached the ending, you're allowed to start over with all your skillpoints and upgrades!

It's so cheap, this game is worth at least a shot (ha ha).
Just so ridiculously satisfying. If you see it on sale, definitely one to get.

One of the best shooters recently. Full of action, great characters and nice story...

While not fantastic, this is a pretty decent game, especially if you like westerns. It folds together a whole bunch of classic Old West historical figures and mythology, with the addition of some in-game collectible cards that give well-written summaries of the real history behind them (as far as is known, anyway). The narrative is delivered pretty cleverly, as well. It's not a very long game, but I thought it was quite nice.

A really solid FPS, especially for the price. It's linear and short, with only 8 weapons (3 pistols, 2 shotguns, 2 rifles, dynamite), but it still manages to have decent pacing, a good sense of humor, very nice visuals (especially the colors!) and overall packs a lot of fun into a small package.
It's very simple - wild wild west, nothing but the best. :)
